THADDEUS GUBALA
January 27, 2015

segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mr. Thaddeus Gubala, or Gubala, as it is known now here in the United States, on January 27, 2015, in Chicago, Illinois. Thank you very much Mr. Gubala, for agreeing to meet with us today, and to share some of your experiences from the war, and from the postwar years. What I’d like to do is talk a great deal about the world, and the life that you had before any of these events, before the war started. So, I’m going to start at the very beginning. Could you tell me, what was your name at birth?
segments.answer: My name at birth — oh, first of all, I would like to thank you for coming and visiting my modest little hacienda, here in the Windy City.

segments.question: Thank you.
segments.answer: And my name originally was Thaddeus Roman Gubala, L with the little slash above.

segments.question: Okay. And what was your date of birth?
segments.answer: Date of birth was February 3", ’29.

segments.question: So that means your birthday is coming up next week.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: In one week.
segments.answer: I will enter the — 86. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala : January 27, 2015

segments.question: Congratulations.
segments.answer: Thank you.

segments.question: And where were you born?
segments.answer: I was born in Warsaw, Warsaw, Poland. This was Hosia(ph) Street three, the building is still existing there.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: This was — yes. Well, it was damaged during the uprising, but still, the structure is there. So whenever I visit Warsaw, I take a glimpse of that building. And during the occupation, actually, I didn’t live in that area.

segments.question: You lived — you were elsewhere?
segments.answer: Yes. But a— my parish was a church, holy — holy — the Alexander Church in Three Crosses Square in Warsaw.

segments.question: Is that the center of town, or is that a little bit outside the center?
segments.answer: I would say it’s close to center, yes, close to center, because the Royal Tr-Track starts from Wilanow, all the way to the old town in Warsaw, but this is part of that section that covers that distance. They call it the Royal Track [speaks Polish] This is in Polish. But Nowy Swiat, the New World, actually started from that square, Three Crosses Square. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ° January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay. What kind of a building did you grow up in? Was it a huge apartment building, or single family —
segments.answer: No, it was in an apart — it was about five story building, five story building, yes.

segments.question: Built when, in the 19 century, or the 20"?
segments.answer: This was, I would say, 20" century already there, yes.

segments.question: Okay. And how modern was it? Did it have electricity, for example?
segments.answer: Oh, there were electricity, yes, electricity. We had the bathrooms —

segments.question: Running water.
segments.answer: Running water, yes, yes.

segments.question: Mm-hm, and plumbing, and all of that. So, it was a modern place.
segments.answer: Yes, it was a modern place. Warsaw is a — as it grew, during the time after the first World War, this was under the Tsarist Russia.

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: But then, when Pilsudski came to power in 1918, Poland regained her independence, after 123 years of nonexistence, so to speak, of — Poland only existed only as partitions.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Poland was divided actually into three segments, and this was Prussian, Russian, and Austro-Hungary. So actually, Warsaw was part of the Tsarist domain. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ° January 27, 2015

segments.question: So, when Poland became independent again, and the three parts became united, 123 years is still quite a while, because it 1s more than living memory. Several generations are comprised in that. Had people changed very much? Could you understand one another — I mean psychologically?
segments.answer: Well, there were different, let’s say, frames that the Poles grew, that say, Germans were very anti-Polish, and Hakatay(ph) was the organization that even forbade the Polish language to be used at schools.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Russians were also trying to bring their influence to the point. And then, the most tolerant part was the au — aus — aus — aus —

segments.question: Austro-Hungarian?
segments.answer: Aust-Austro-Hungarian part. Yeah, so that was was a — a little better for schooling, secondary schooling and so on. And let’s say Poles from Galicia?

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: You know, they were a little different in character than let’s say, Poles that were slightly Germanized under the ger — the Prussian operation, and the Poles living under the Russians. So, this process of fusing us together was actually a great, let’s say, accomplishment of the Catholic church, because they mostly — the Poles were of Catholic faith, and that was — the church was actually the strongest party that Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ' January 27, 2015 existed in — in Poland. But then when Pilsudski became the Marshall of Poland — this was in 1914, and officially Poland regained her independence in the *18, he was assigned a task of, let’s say, fusing th-the different characters of people that grew in different segments of the country.

segments.question: So what were some of the — I mean, just curiosity — you say the Galicianas are different than those who were — and Galicia was under Austro-Hungarian rule?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What kind of character did the one have in comparison to the other two, and so on?
segments.answer: Let’s say the — the — let’s say the Germans, Poles, from the German part, from the Prussian part were, let’s say, a little bit more like Germans, very orderly, let’s say the work that they accomplished was more thorough than let’s say the group of Poles in the east, under the Russians. And let’s say the Galicians were also a little bit closer to — to — to — to German influence. But all together, united by the faith, you know, we were very quickly re — reburn(ph).

segments.question: Reborn.
segments.answer: Reborn, yes, reborn.

segments.question: Yeah. And tell me a little bit — so, there are questions that I usually ask people who were in the eastern territories, that don’t apply here, but I will just bring them Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ° January 27, 2015 up. And that is, one of the — the issues that I want to find out about is the degree of modernization. So there I will ask, you know, did anybody have a radio? Did anybody have a telephone? Did they ha — did — were cars — automobiles common to see? Well, in the center of Warsaw, I would assume that these things —
segments.answer: Yes, the Poland was called — they called Poland at that time — the Warsaw was the — the — the Paris of the east.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That was — city was about one point two million people. And there — there was, let’s see, very large Jewish diaspora in Warsaw. The diaspora was about 400,00, so every third Warsawian was of — of Hebrew faith. Some of them got more or less Poland-ized, then the — they were, let’s say, getting with the Poles closer, and the other ones were dep — Poland was free, as far as the religion is concerned, so they had their ow-own synagogues, they had their own traditions, and they grew in the environment that their predecessors are sort of giving them. But —

segments.question: Did you — mm-hm, go ahead.
segments.answer: And Warsaw — Warsaw was specially — some districts of Warsaw were predominantly Jewish. The most famous synagogue was the synagogue on Tlomackie Street. Now, if you ever visit Warsaw at that area, was — actually is a Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015 skyscraper about 40 stories high, a blue building that was, let’s say built after the war, in that area where that synagogue was.

segments.question: Is there —
segments.answer: And this was the most beautiful synagogue in the world, the largest, and —

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Even though you weren’t Jewish — you aren’t Jewish, did you ever visit inside? Did you ever —
segments.answer: Oh, my father — my father was always very, how should I say, trying to show me the — the cerkiew, which is the Orthodox church, we had one big chur — cerkiew in Praga. Because Praga is not the Czech Prague, it’s a— Warsaw was on the left bank of the Vistula, looking north was Warszawa, was Warsaw. On the right side was Praga.

segments.question: So it was like a — a district of Warsaw, a section of Warsaw.
segments.answer: Well yes, th-the eastern part, you know, the bridges connected the city together.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And there was a cerkiew, there was the Russian Orthodox church. And very often he took me over to show the — how they pray, and how they, let’s say, celebrate their different religious — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015

segments.question: Services.
segments.answer: — services. And there was a — in — 1n Warsaw I visited synagogues from time to time. Actually in my classroom, I had many Jewish friends that especially — Thursdays were the days when they were teaching us religion; history of the Catholic churches, or at that time the — the Jewish minority was excused, they could take a walk into the park, play soccer, or whatever. [phone ringing]

segments.question: Let’s cut. [break] So, you were talking about something very interesting.
segments.answer: Th-Thursday —

segments.question: Oh, hang on a minute, let’s —
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: Yeah, you were talking about Thursdays at school.
segments.answer: Thursdays at school. So, the — let’s say, students, pupils that were excused for that day, of Jewish faith, you know, so very often I — I — I joined them just to be out in the park, and play soccer. That —

segments.question: I was — yeah, I was going to say, weren’t you jealous of those kids who didn’t have to go to class?
segments.answer: That’s right, you know, so I was what, eight, seven — seven, eight years old, so at that time it was okay.

segments.question: So, did you ever visit this beautiful synagogue you told us — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yes —

segments.question: — when you were [indecipherable]
segments.answer: — I visited that synagogue. Yes, this was in 1936 or ’37, yeah, with my father.

segments.question: So you were bor — yeah.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Do you have —
segments.answer: Nowadays — nowadays they have Tlomackie Street, and there is a — a Jewish, let’s say library, and — and a small museum, because the main museum that was erected just th — one year ago, open up, it’s one of the most beautiful, modern museum, they spend a lot of money. And I think the — the help came from the good, old U.S.A., you know, so — and then fa — I think contribution was also made by the Polish president to build in the area where they have nalewki(ph), and that was that infamous Umschlagplatz. That’s was the — the Jews were loaded on the trucks, and taken over to Treblinka. So this was ex-Jewish district.

segments.question: So, was the Umschlagplatz within the space of the ghetto, or outside of it?
segments.answer: Umschlagplatz was on the periphery of ghetto, you know, but it was inside, inside yes.

segments.question: It was inside, but at the edge. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And the railroad tracks at Stawki, there were, I think five tracks that the trains were coming in, because there was a — sort of like a 10 — 10,000 — 10,000 a day were trying to unload from Warsaw and send them to Treblinka.

segments.question: So when — when — when Jews were being loaded onto — you’d say trucks, and then to trains, or how would they be —
segments.answer: No, they were — they were — they were walking toward the tra — Umschlagplatz. There were no trucks actually in the ghetto, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: They were streetcars, but they were not used. Normally the cruel police force were the actually Jewish police, because they were obliged to bring the contingent of so many Jews for that particular day, that were shipped to Treblinka.

segments.question: So they would go by foot to the Umschlagplatz?
segments.answer: But foot, with — they were normally told that they are going east for some places that they will be employed and work for the upkeep of their own lives, and so on. So they were — they were lied about this designation of Treblinka, because this was the end of the trip, so to speak, of —

segments.question: Yeah. And it was by train?
segments.answer: By train, yes. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015

segments.question: By train. Now, you say this was within the ghetto — the ghetto itself, but on the periphery. Did you ever see anything like this, were you able to see it?
segments.answer: No, I - let’s see. I had my school located — let’s start from a different point. There were two ghettos actually. There was small ghetto, south of Wolska Street, which was main thoroughfare through Warsaw.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And there was a large ghetto north of it.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And normally they build a wall around small and large ghettos, so this whole area was isolated. Along the Wolska Street, between Wronia and Zelazna, this was a point where two ghettos were —

segments.question: Connected?
segments.answer: — connected, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And they were also at the place like Zelazna and Chlodna, this was a bridge that was connecting small ghetto with large ghetto. That bridge you could see in that film of pianist, by —

segments.question: That’s right, by Roman Polanski. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Polanski, yes. This bridge I remember well, and that portion of wall, and the main gate to the ghetto, I remember very well because my school was like — during the occupation, you know, the secondary schooling was forbidden for the Poles.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Hitler wanted us only to know how to count to a hundred, write and read, and that’s it. And we were designated for what they call konnektenvolk(ph).

segments.question: Konnektenvolk(ph).
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: What is konnektenvolk(ph)?
segments.answer: Konnekten(ph), it — it’s a subdue human beings working for the —

segments.question: Overlords.
segments.answer: — overlords, yes.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So this was — this was school located — trade school, actually, this was trade school, because no secondary schools were allowed. But in that trade school we had schooling, secondary schooling undercover, we say. We used to say yeah, pod pokrywka gymnasium pod pokrywka. The secondary school was under the cover. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala : January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So even we had the universities and polytechnics, everything was unofficially forbidden, but underground was acting. So, going to my trade school — actually, this was the first class of gymnasium we call it, high school, I was passing the main gate

segments.question: Of the ghetto.
segments.answer: — and actually right by that bridge, what you saw in that film.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Walking there. So this was close. This portion was Aryan portion, so we saw it, everything what was going on behind the wall.

segments.question: So you would see over the wall?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What were the things that you were seeing?
segments.answer: Well, the buildings. The street was divided by the wall, and these houses there, the — cause ghetto was overpopulated. At that time, some of the houses are already empty, because that process of sending Jews to the death chambers in Treblinka was — vacated a lot of space, leaving space in the buildings. So that was neglected. On top of the wall, actually, the Germans set up machine guns. There were, actually at that time, some of the people that came from the ukra — Ukraine — Ukrainians Interview with Thaddeus Gubala me January 27, 2015 were guarding the Jewish ghetto, and Latvians were guarding the Jewish ghetto. And the Germans were in the supervisory positions.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So what I saw there? I remember when the Jewish uprising started, this —

segments.question: Well, we’ll talk about that later on.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: We'll go back now to —
segments.answer: So guide me to whatever —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — because I don’t want to jump from one —

segments.question: That’s okay.
segments.answer: — subject to another —

segments.question: That’s okay.
segments.answer: — because this gonna be a —

segments.question: You’re — yeah, bu-but you’re explaining things in a very interesting fashion. And we started with the synagogue, and the beautiful synagogue that — that was there before the war. And I’d like to ask — you know, you were a young boy when you were there.
segments.answer: Yes. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015

segments.question: But do you remember anything from the inside of that synagogue, of what it looked like to you?
segments.answer: Not the — the — the altar, the decorations, the building, the walls. I have a picture, but not too vivid, you know.

segments.question: Was it big? Was it a —
segments.answer: Hm? Oh yes, very large. Very large building. Very large building there. There was a Torah displayed there, and that seven — seven candles.

segments.question: The menorah.
segments.answer: Yeah, menorah. Then th — then I remember, and I listened to some of the can- cantors? I used to hear the singers.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So they had the very good singers.

segments.question: Did you go during service times?
segments.answer: Mm — no, no, no. But they had some practices during that time, so that we walked in and we were permitted to look around, and —

segments.question: Mm-hm. Well, it sounds — 1t was unusual that your father would think of it, to take you to the churches of different religions, and the worshipping houses of different religions. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: You know, war — Warsaw was actually like an international sort of a metropoly(ph), and we had the majority Poles, okay, that was about 800,000 Poles at that time, and 400,000 were Jews. But we had Germans, we had Lithuanians, and different nationalities living in — in — in Warsaw.

segments.question: And your father, was he a — an international kind of person?
segments.answer: No, no, no.

segments.question: No? So what was his reason for bringing you to these places?
segments.answer: Well, he wanted to — let’s say to satisfy my curiosity. I was always, let’s say, curious of what the other people, how they pray, what they do, and how the ceremony goes, you — so I — I remember when I visited cerkiew, which was that Orthodox. The only thing that was — that I remember was the — a lot of herbs, and holy —

segments.question: The incense.
segments.answer: — things — in — yes, th-they were burning, and the smoke of it, you know, then — then I started —

segments.question: Tearing up.
segments.answer: — getting tears in my — tearing up, and then he said okay, that’s — that’s enough. But he — he wanted me to know, let’s say, what the city is like. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala © January 27, 2015

segments.question: Mm-hm. Let’s — let’s turn a little bit then to your own home, which is, I started asking about the physical, how it looked physically, and if you could paint a picture for me.
segments.answer: Our — our apartment was, let’s say, within a complex — that was industrial complex. My father was working for the transportation com — company, and where he was in the — in this storage, purchasing the tires, different parts for the buses that were in the workshop, repaired. Our apartment consisted of one large room. There was a bed, and two bedrooms, and a kitchen.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: You know, for Warsaw that was a nice —

segments.question: Nice size.
segments.answer: Nice size of place. And the next, adjacent building was a large building, built during the Tsarist times, I think, that they had three different factories. That was a textile factory, there was some mechanical shop, and the top was some chemical establishment there. So we didn’t have many neighbors, you say civilians, because we were part of that industrial complex. My mother was running a little cafeteria, for one place, and the father was working for the Polska Linia Samochodowa, which was the transportation company.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Was it a private company, or state-owned company? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: I would say this was a private company, yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay. Okay. And the — and was it that 1t was the co — a company apartment? That is, it belonged to the company, but people who worked there could rent them out?
segments.answer: Yes, th-this is — this — when we moved from Hosia(ph) Street, because this part here is Krochmatna part. This is away from the center of the city. This was in the suburb called Wola, w-o-l-a, Wola.

segments.question: I see. And when did you move there? How old were you?
segments.answer: That — I was, let’s say I was about five years old or so when we moved there. And we lived there throughout, let’s see, siege of Warsaw in 1939, and during the occupation, until I was deported.

segments.question: I see. So 1t was your home.
segments.answer: That was my home, yes.

segments.question: That was your home. Did you have brothers and sisters?
segments.answer: I had a sister.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yes, she was older, about four or five years older than I am.

segments.question: So she was born in the mid-20s, something like that?
segments.answer: She was born in 1924, and my vintage was, as I mentioned, ’29. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala a January 27, 2015

segments.question: What was her name?
segments.answer: Helena.

segments.question: Is she still alive?
segments.answer: No, no, no. She was so exhausted actually, she died in Germany.

segments.question: You mean, during the war?
segments.answer: Wa — after — after —

segments.question: Right after the war?
segments.answer: Yeah. Yes.

segments.question: I see. What was your mother’s name?
segments.answer: Mother name was Maria.

segments.question: And your father’s?
segments.answer: Piotr. Peter.

segments.question: Peter.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And your mother’s maiden name?
segments.answer: Wlodarski.

segments.question: Maria Wlodarski.
segments.answer: Wlodarski.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: W-1-o-d-a-r-s-k-i.

segments.question: Okay. Were they — were they vars — Warsawians?
segments.answer: My mother was born in vicinity of Kielce.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And my father was Warsawian, yes, but he lived with his folks in — near — near Kielce. And we lived in Hosia(ph) Street, as I mentioned.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Did you have aunts and uncles, and larger family?
segments.answer: Oh yes, my mother’s brother, we owned a little summer home in Otwock that was east — east of Warsaw, within the network of electrical trains. So we were communicating on weekends to Stara Wies.

segments.question: Stara Wies.
segments.answer: Old village.

segments.question: And it was — and Otwock was a region, or a village, or a town?
segments.answer: No, Otwock was the largest city that the electrical train was — had the terminal there. So Stara WieS was [indecipherable] and Stara Wies, this was couple kilometers east of Otwock. Otwock was larger — larger —

segments.question: City.
segments.answer: — city, yes.

segments.question: Okay. And how far was it from Warsaw? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala oS January 27, 2015
segments.answer: This was around, let’s say, 30 kilometers or so.

segments.question: So it was almost like a suburb.
segments.answer: Yes, almost like a suburb. Now, as the Warsaw is growing, the Otwock is getting closer and closer.

segments.question: I remember the — I remember Otwock, because there was a diary of a ghetto policeman from Otwock that was written. A very interesting book —
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: — and a very heartrending book, because he was writing about his dilemma being a policeman. He did not survive the war.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Now Otwock I also knew during the occupation, but maybe that’s a subject we should touch later on, that —

segments.question: Well, let’s see, and we’ll see.
segments.answer: When the Germans caught me at the main railroad station, because we had some business with the Hungarians, or Romanians and Germans, that was going to the eastern front, you know, to — for a — for a cover-up I used to be selling cigarettes or newspapers, something, because we deal — we dealt with the Hungarians and the other soldiers for schnapps. We could buy some good material for our, let’s say weapons, even pistols and so on. So when I was arrested by the Germans, I was young — 12 years — or 12 - 13 years old, and they put me in the prison on Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala a“ January 27, 2015 Poznanska Street, and I — they kept me there — because Germans actually gave to the blue policeman. We had Polish police. On the Polish side they were in blue uniforms, and the German gendarmerie, that was the German police that actually cooperated with the Polish policemen. And they gave me, as a youngster to the blue policemen, and they put me in jail. So I spend there a few weeks, and what happened is that I— I was young, undernourished, and I had some beginning of tuberculosis. So the Polish underground, when they saw what was happening to me, they sent me to Olenika(ph), which was the sanitortum near Otwock.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And there I was, let’s say, for a few months, to kill that —

segments.question: Tuberculosis?
segments.answer: — beginning to — tuberculosis, I had sha — shadows in my lungs that were the sarg — larger size of a plum or an apple. And this finally was arrested and calcinations were formed, and I didn’t have an open tuberculosis. So they saved my life, so to speak. Tu-Tuberculosis was, during the time of occupation of Poland was a very common problem, because people are undernourished, and —

segments.question: Was it a killer?
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: Wa — did people die from tuberculosis? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala _ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes, yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Open tuberculosis is very contagious.

segments.question: Okay. So there are many reasons to try and catch it, not only for the person themselves, but so that it wouldn’t become infectious and an epi — an epidemic.
segments.answer: Yes, yes. No, the — the — it was very close to epidemic, because we were receiving about 1500 calories, and that was not enough to — to — to die, and not enough to live normal life.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So the Poles were starving, but the poor Jewish guys, they were even worse, because they were getting about 500 calories a day. So they were destined for death.

segments.question: Yeah. Okay, let’s return prewar. Was your family very religious?
segments.answer: I would say yes; Father especially, and my mother. And nearby — I mentioned the church where I was baptized; this was the Saint Alexander church on Three Crosses Square in Warsaw. But when we moved, we belonged to Saint Clement’s.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: These were the — oh, I forgot that — maybe it will come back to me, but the parish nearby, we were members of that parish, and during the uprising, and during Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “° January 27, 2015 the occupation, we attended the masses regularly on — on Sunday. And that was only couple blocks away. This church actually, I found that was damaged, yes, damaged, but it was rebuilt, and it’s still existing in.

segments.question: So did you go weekly to — was it a— was it a family tradition to go to mass every Sunday?
segments.answer: Yes, every Sunday we went to mass, and — at this church, or church — Boromeusz Church. This was close to the main entrance to the ghetto. This was at the point where I mentioned street Zelazna. Actually at that point Wlodna and Elektoralna, that was a Y, sort of branches, that the church was in that triangle.

segments.question: Oh, I see.
segments.answer: And this was something that I had to be there on Sundays, and some other big holidays, because that was sort of obligatory from the school.

segments.question: Ah. So —
segments.answer: So the school — the schools’ students, pupils, were going to that special mass for the students.

segments.question: And that would be on a school day, or on Sundays?
segments.answer: This was Sundays, and major holidays —

segments.question: Holidays.
segments.answer: — yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ot January 27, 2015

segments.question: Saint days and things.
segments.answer: This was before the war.

segments.question: Yes, I’m talking before the war.
segments.answer: Before the war, yes.

segments.question: Yeah, before the war. And you said that you had — it was a public school that you went to?
segments.answer: Yes, the school was number 100. It was a new building, built during the 20 years of Polish independence, and I remember it very well, because that was a walking distance. And school was very clean, well illuminated. We used to have a very soft — soft slippers that we couldn’t bring the shoes normally from the street, with the hard soles that would damage shining floors. Nice windows, big windows; classrooms were spacious. So that was a nice time that I had during the time til 1939 —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — attending. And I finished, I think the fourth grade.

segments.question: In — and — by 1939.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. Tell me a little bit about your mother and father’s own family histories. Had they, either of them finished university, or gone to university? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: No, my — no, they didn’t have a higher education. My mother completed high school; and Father, he was sort of a business-minded man, and he did not get university studies behind him. But he was, let’s say a junior college, education- wise. And he served, during the time when Poland was still partitioned, he served in the Austria army, so his German was excellent, and partially I inherited the German language from him. So he was — during the occupation, he was employed by the Ostbahn. Ostbahn, east railroad — the Germans had westbound, eastbound, Reich-bahn. So this was part of the Reich-bahn, and he was, as an interpreter, working at the main central station there.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Well, that’s quite an interesting position to have.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: So you were — the main central station for the ost, for the east.
segments.answer: For the east.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yes. This was located on the Jerusalem alley, and it’s still there, but the building was completely, let’s say, destroyed, but that area was used for the new structure that is the center Warsaw station. Very nice building, near — near that — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015 what do they call it, the gift from Stalin, near the palace of the — the Stalin palace, but this was —

segments.question: Oh, I think I know the building you mean.
segments.answer: —a-—a left — did you see that building?

segments.question: It looks almost like the one at mo — in Moscow, with similar structure.
segments.answer: Yes. This was a style that the Russians ca — kept, that they preserved building the structures according to the drawings that they made for their university in Moscow. So the Alexanderplatz in Berlin was similar to this. Well, this was despised by the Poles, th-they used to laugh. I remember the first visit in Poland in 1950 — ’59, when driving with the guy that was a taxi driver, he asked me, says, the best view of Warsaw? You know where you get the best view of Warsaw’? He says, the best view of Warsaw you get from the palace. I said, oh yeah? Why is that so? Well, cause when you in the palace, you don’t see the palace. You know, so —

segments.question: Even the taxi driver.
segments.answer: Even the taxi driver, yes. He says that he — he was going a little further, he says, even that antenna that they built — they built that was a protective weapon that no Pole could climb up on the very top and do things, dirty things. They hated the structure, you know. It’s still existing. It’s like a monument of the Russian occupation of — of Poland. And this was a gift. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015

segments.question: I see. I see.
segments.answer: My wife re — remembers this vividly because she was witnessing the erection of that —

segments.question: The construction of this building.
segments.answer: The construction of this, yes. I saw it finished. Now it’s dark. When — when you see when the two systems meet, the — th-the monument of the communism, versus against the — the — the capitalism, so to speak, of the skyscrapers, you know, na — modern buildings. It is — it 1s a contrast that you cannot simply understand, you know, how the Russians could build such a awful structure in the midst of that modern new Warsaw that is growing — growing up.

segments.question: Well, you know, in — architecture has its own stories. In architecture and geography too. You know, geography you would think is such a neutral subject, but geography encompasses maps and street names, and those changed so often, because of whatever political force happened to be in power in this part of the world. Okay —
segments.answer: You can — you can actually take a — Poland as an example of a migratory nation, because when you look — when you look at the history, the union with Lithuania was what, 15"" century, when we were one country, Poland was actually the largest Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015 state in — in — in —1n Europe; from the Black Sea all the way to the black — Baltic Sea.

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: And the borders were changing so much, going eastbound, westbound, and that’s why the Poles are of some different characters, because the days of occupation changed the people. And since the borders moved, the people moved.

segments.question: That’s true, that’s true.
segments.answer: That was tr-tragic in a way, but when Polish borders were set up in Yalta, Potsdam and other places where the destiny of Poland was set up with the matches, they were laughing that Churchill, Stalin and President Roosevelt, they were setting up the borders of Poland with the m —

segments.question: With the matchsticks.
segments.answer: — matches. And then the famous Curzon line, the [indecipherable] of Curzon, you know, that divided the portion of eastern part of Poland, and the western part of Poland.

segments.question: You mean during the war itself?
segments.answer: During the war itself. In 1939 — we jumping from subject to subject.

segments.question: We are. It’s okay. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015
segments.answer: But that mixture maybe will give you a little better idea what — that time, in °39, there was that infamous pact of Ribbentrop-Molotov. Thirty-nine when the Russia was befriended with Reich.

segments.question: With Germany.
segments.answer: With Germany. And this was — we call it the fourth partition of Poland, and the border line, Curzon Line actually came into picture. Because now — it — there is a certain similarity what they doing now in Ukraine, you know, when they coming to protect their brothers and sisters, living in the administrative territory of eastern Ukraine, that was happening in the eastern part of Poland. They came to resc — rescue the Ukrainians minority that lived there, and the Byelorussian minority, and all the part of north — northeast part of Poland that’s Lithuania nowadays. They were trying to save their people from the Polish tyranny. So the borders were moving and then we sometimes laughed that we have Poles with so many German names, and we have Germans with the Polish names.

segments.question: It got all mixed.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: It got all mixed, and — through all of these chess players —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — you know, on the — on the field. Let’s go back again. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Okay.

segments.question: Let’s go back again. In the — at — I wanted to find out more about your families’ histories. That is, what kind of a family did your father come from, and that your mother came from?
segments.answer: They were, let’s say Father, his brother owned a larger piece of land near Kielce. And Mother was living in that area, before they moved into Warsaw.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So they were rather the agricultural, farmer — farmers.

segments.question: Farm people.
segments.answer: Yes. And when they lived in Warsaw, they changed their style completely.

segments.question: Oh, did they?
segments.answer: Yes, because you know, as they came from the smaller — smaller places, into big city like this. So this was a major change —

segments.question: Did they feel —
segments.answer: — in their style of life.

segments.question: Did they feel — were they comfortable in Warsaw —
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes.

segments.question: — did they feel good — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Sister, for instance — we di — we were not rich, but we were pretty well-to-do, and Sister was going to ballet school. I was going to the normal public school, but later on, during the occupation, they had to dish out money so I could go to the secondary school, unofficial —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — secondary schools. And the sister was much older than I am, so she was continuing that — let’s say musical education that she wanted to finish, but that was very difficult. Difficult because living conditions were very —

segments.question: Hard.
segments.answer: Living conditions were rough, very rough. People were rather concerned how to survive from day to day. They couldn’t have any plans at all.

segments.question: Yeah. You —
segments.answer: I remember as a kid I used to say goodbye to my parents going to school, because I didn’t know whether I — I am gonna come back, you know, in peace. So city was living in a very, how shall I say, warlike atmosphere. Strit — streets were not safe. Streetcars were — very often street was blocked, and people were taken by force into the — the trucks, and put into the camp to be sent to work in — in — in Germany. Slave laborers. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015

segments.question: So, it just — you wouldn’t know, when you were on the streetcar, whether or not you ll make your destination.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Is that what you’re saying?
segments.answer: Yes. Nervousness. Nervousness was a controlled — a very rude way by the Germans. At the beginning — that was — I’m speaking of 1940, very rough winter in Warsaw, because it was very cold, and then ’42 — 42, ’41 — °42, when the separation of the population was getting to the point that they build the ghetto, and they separated Aryan population from the Jewish population. And then ’43, the conditions started changing where that German behavior, after Korksk(ph) and Stalingrad changed their attitude. They sort of mellowed down, you know, that’s — that greeting of high Hitler, with the hand raised very high, changed a little bit like, just in case we lose, high Hitler with the little — smaller — smaller gesture. We were laughing, and — but we sensed that was a city that was witnessing the change in the German attitude. Stalingrad was a major — major change in the German bravura, the German spirit of vic-victory for any cost.

segments.question: So, I'll ask one question about this, and then I want to go back still, to pre-war. Did people know about German losses in Stalingrad? I mean, after all, they controlled the media. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala *° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes, they — let’s say, the German propaganda was very strong when the Operation Barbarossa starts. You know, they named — the code name Barbarossa was the time when the Germans attacked Russia. This was a sh — shock.

segments.question: So you mean June 21*?
segments.answer: I am saying June 21“, I think, 1941. Am I correct?

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Yeah, ’41. And th-the Operation Barbarossa was observed by us very closely. I was already a part of the —

segments.question: Don’t talk about that, just about — I — what I wanted to know about is, how much did people know about the Battle of Stalingrad in ’43?
segments.answer: Stalingrad. Let’s say, we drew conclusions what was happening in the eastern front, when we saw trains going through Warsaw with the German sol — German soldiers, you know, that no ears, no noses, no hands, because of the frostbites, from that famous Russian general. You know the fis — famous Russian general? What was his name?

segments.question: General — General Winter.
segments.answer: General Winter, yes.

segments.question: Yes. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And we were witnessing, plus the Germans themselves were telling these stories, and somehow the rumor was spreading out among — and then we had envoys from the Polish Home Army that were going sometimes eastbound. And they knew what was happening. Plus, we were getting the news from the BBC.

segments.question: That’s interesting.
segments.answer: See, the radios were confiscated. All radios were confiscated when the Germans entered. But we were smart enough not to give all the radios away.

segments.question: Did your family have a radio?
segments.answer: Oh yes, before the war we had a radio, because Mama, as I said, my mother was running that little cafeteria for the radio producer. Radio Union(ph).

segments.question: Oh, so she wasn’t working for the same organization as your father, she was running a cafeteria for another organization?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: So this, to make the ends meet, you know, both of them were working to send us through schools, and all the exp —

segments.question: Did she have any help at home for — I mean, hired help, or did she do everything? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala . January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Oh yeah, Stefcha(ph) — Stefcha(ph) — Steffa(ph) — Steffa(ph) was the girl that was actually sort of taking care of us —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: —my sister and I.

segments.question: Okay. Okay, so before the war, you had a radio.
segments.answer: We had the radio, we had telephone. That was not the modern, you know, iPhone like we have here. That was on the wall, with that little receiver that you are putting in, the dial —

segments.question: You mean, your phone — your phone wasn’t a map service, and wasn’t a laundry service, and wasn’t a camera as well, like the iPhone is?
segments.answer: No. No, we could call, let’s say, the operator for a weather report, or things like that, but that was the long way.

segments.question: That’s right. So — so you had a phone, you had a radio. Did your parents own an automobile?
segments.answer: Let’s say, that was time when we had a couple cars that we rented for tax1.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: For taxi, you know. So later on, when there was no gas, there were no need for cars. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015

segments.question: So you rent — your family rented cars out and used them as taxis to make money? Is this what there was —
segments.answer: No, it’s a— when that firm actually was very close to — to bankruptcy, you know.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Father received this, I should say, a premium, like, that were two cars that he repaired, and then he rented out to the guys that were taxi drivers.

segments.question: Oh, and so he got some — some — he got some percentage of that.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: I see. So the firm that he was working in, which was — tell me again, it was —
segments.answer: First Galena(ph) Samochodowa.

segments.question: And that was to do parts for buses, right?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: To buy parts for —
segments.answer: These were — these were the intercity buses. Not like a Greyhound, or —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Much smaller, but they were going from city to city, alongside the railroads.

segments.question: And did that — did that company go bankrupt before the war?
segments.answer: No, no, this lasted til 1939. Actually, some of the buses, some of the cars were requisitioned by the army when the war started in 1939. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I remember a visit of some high ranking officers that came over, and they were discussing what cars can be used by the army.

segments.question: The Polish army.
segments.answer: Polish army, yes.

segments.question: Okay. Okay, now I want to turn to another subject; again, before the war. What were the kinds of conversations that you would have around the dinner table with your family? Did you talk about political events, and political things?
segments.answer: Say Poles all together, they have, let’s say, great interest in — in politics. And especially since Poland was exposed to all different, let’s say pressures from the west, from the east. Discussions at the table, and friends of my father came over. They were officers from the — active officers from the — from the Polish army. They discuss at the table the issues of Poland being such a strong country, that they — the Germans will attack Poland, we will resist, and then so on, and so on. So the talks were on the subject of military efforts, and — an-and Europe at that time was sort of sensing oncoming second World War. So these discussions, I remember that the father was discussing this. But when we had gatherings that my mother’s brother coming from Otwock for — sometimes for a weekends, or summertime, so we were going there, discussions were different, you know. Our schooling time, and then Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015 changes in the economy that were improving little by little; because you know, country was actually devastated during the first World War, and the oppressors, the occupiers, they — they were taking their share. So we could not develop, just like western Europe developed free, and that momentum that they had could not be, let’s say, shown 1n the Polish economy.

segments.question: Well, here’s a question that’s a bit provocative, and I know in advance that it is. But there is the image, that when the war started, and Germany crossed the border into Poland with tanks, they were met by cavalry officers on horses and swords.
segments.answer: This is — actually, this was a false story. Some of the big cavalry units were surrounded by the German, let’s say motorized units. And when they locked in, they tried to escape, but they were not, let’s say, crazy enough to attack with the lances against the German tanks, no.

segments.question: Okay. I mean — I-I mean more that Poland was so unprepared that it didn’t have tanks of its own, that it didn’t have modern military equipment. Is that so, or is that a falsehood?
segments.answer: That’s falsehood. We had air force.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That’s a— not as modern as the Germans had, but very effective.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015
segments.answer: We had our own design, let’s say WSK Kalisz and that PZL-11. These airplanes were not large in numbers, because this was a developing industry in Poland, the aircraft industry. The tanks, they were not built in Poland, but we had tanks vic — Vickers tanks from — imported from England. And we had the motorized units. We had the motorized brigade that actually later on, became the first armored division in the west, under General Maczek, af you — if you heard.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Okay.
segments.answer: And when — when Poland army was formed, let’s say we had so much experience with the enemies that the army was indoctrinated well enough to be spiritually strong. Equipment-wise, we were inferiors to Germans. We were inferiors — spirit of fighting was much stronger maybe that the Germans had.

segments.question: So the morale was high.
segments.answer: Morality of the army was high, morale was high, but the equipment was inferior, inferior. But very effective. Because remember, when the — when the Germans attacked us from three directions, actually; from East Prussia, going south; from the Reich, they were going east, and from the south, they were attacked through — Czechoslovakia was already annexed by the — by the Reich, by the Germany.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Right. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And at that time also Slovakia joined the German camp. So we had some — part of the invasion of ch — Slovaks into Poland, the German armies, and then armies from the East Prussia that was coming in.

segments.question: And that was all September 1“, 1939?
segments.answer: Yes, September 1939. So, wi— most of our defenses were directed against the Germans coming from the west. We did not expect the Russians will stab us in the back on the 17" of September. They attacked to come and free their people that were living in Kresy, which was the Volhynia, Polesie, Podole, and the Nowogrdodek, closer to Lithuania, as we were. So Kresy were liberated, quotation marks, by the — by the Russians.

segments.question: So there was no knowledge of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact in Poland’?
segments.answer: In Poland”

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Yes, there was knowledge, yes, we knew, we knew about it, yes.

segments.question: At the time?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: Because it was signed one week before the war started. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yes, but we knew it. Don’t forget that the Polish dwika(ph), which was the, let’s say, compared to — to FBI or CIA, the Secret Service, and so on, we had a very good sensors everywhere in — in —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — in Prussia and in — in Germany, especially in Berlin. And —

segments.question: So you had intelligence reports, the con — the government had intelligence reports.
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay. But then —
segments.answer: And these were prior to the — prior to the outbreak of the war. We were pretty well advanced in decoding German messages. “Enigma” is — that’s the movie nowadays —

segments.question: Uh-huh, right.
segments.answer: — going on, I don’t know if you see it. I didn’t see it, but I would like to see it, because there was a great contribution to the victory of the allied effort during the second World War, by giving the — giving the English and French the secrets of enigma. What was started was the getting in, was the mathematical school that the Poles attended in 1932. And the connections that the Germany had with East Prussia was via the enigma. They were sending codes, and all different secret Interview with Thaddeus Gubala . January 27, 2015 information. So the Poles started getting interest in it, and Zygalski, Rafski(ph), and there was a third name that I forgot, but the — these were the three codebreakers, later on that they work for the Polish secret service. And this was in July 1939, when from England, Poland signed the agreement to be defended by England and France, in case that we get attacked by the Germans. But anyway, going back to that point that the British paid a visit to Poland, Pery(ph) was the name of the town in the suburb of Warsaw. Poles had copied two machines that were intercepted. When they send this to East Prussia, it went via Warsaw. So the secret service took the machines, dismembered them, photographed them, do everything possible to reproduce the machines. And some of the copies were so identical that the Germans wouldn’t be able to recognize which is the original, which is the copy.

segments.question: Oh, so then you started fueling disinformation?
segments.answer: Yeah, so when they came over, the British, Knox and Denniston, I think, they were two gentlemen, and the Frenchman, Bernard, Colonel Bernard came over, and they were actually exchanging their accomplishment that field of cryptology, with the Poles. And they were very surprised when the Poles simply showed them that, we have two gifts from you. One machine for the British, M — M — MI-6, I believe, and the French secret — military secret to Colonel Bernard.

segments.question: So they gave these two enigma — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Enigmas to our allies.

segments.question: I see. Okay, this shows how much you know about — I mean, very few people know the detail of this — these sorts of events. But when I asked of the Molotov- Ribbentrop Pact, and did people know about it, I— I need to be more precise. Did the man on the street know about it, or did the government know about it?
segments.answer: I'd say, speaking of government, Polish government, when Poland was attacked, escaped, with a lot of trained personnel; most of the Polish airmen went through Romania — Romania was ally of Poland — and most of them escaped through Hungary and Romania to the west.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So when the government left Poland, ji— was General Rydz-Smigly, and Moscicki was the president. Moscicki was actually a — as — a Swiss. He was educated in Switzerland and so on. But anyway, when they left, the official, legal Polish government was formed in France. In exile, they — we called it.

segments.question: Of course.
segments.answer: So through that government, and the connections of the Polish underground, and the government in France, and later on when France was defeated, they moved to London. And then came picture of President Raczkiewicz, if you know, and then Sikorski, General Sikorski. He was a premier of the Polish government in exile. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Through that government, and the connections of Polish underground, you know, there was an exchange of news, views, and interviews, whatever was happening in the west, and especially in the Germany. You know, so —

segments.question: So that — so —
segments.answer: —so they were well informed. The members of the underground in Poland was — were — were very well informed of what was behind the screen going on.

segments.question: All right. What about people like your family, like your neighbors. Did you know of — of — were — were — was the regular person in Warsaw as well informed, or were they surprised? Because you see, when you say something like, the Soviet Union stabbed Poland in the back, that — that suggests a surprise. And if you’re very well informed, you won’t be surprised.
segments.answer: Let’s say, we had so many refugees in Warsaw during the war, as the Germans advanced from the west —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — toward Warsaw. Eight — on the eighth day of operations, they were already at the gates of Warsaw. So we had refugees coming from the west into Warsaw, and we had refugees coming from the east into Warsaw. So, this melting pot, this city, Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ™ January 27, 2015 the capital city was sort of a source of all kind of gossip; good news, bad news. So the people were pretty well informed.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Even the — in the streets, average Pole not maybe educated well enough, but still

segments.question: Knew something.
segments.answer: — people say.

segments.question: People talk.
segments.answer: And this was an exchange of news. Plus, you know, we had hidden radios, we were listening to the BBC.

segments.question: Okay. So now I’ve jumped ahead a little bit. I want to go back to the very beginning. Do you remem — the very beginning of the war. Do you remember where you were on September 1“, 1939?
segments.answer: September 1, 1939, prior the day to that outbreak and attack by the Germans, I was walking with my sister toward the deli store nearby, and we were talking about — because the — that was in the atmosphere that Poles — we are so strong that if they attacked us, the third day, our forces will be in Berlin, you know. So I talked to my sister, I says, would you be — Helena, would you be interested to — to — to see the Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015 war, what it is like? And she says yes, it will be very interesting. So, as kids, you know, young people, we were talking about the oncoming disaster.

segments.question: And you were 10, and she was 14.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. It’s — you were kids.
segments.answer: Yes. The kids, but you know, th-th — the kids, let’s say, in — in — in adopted country, here in United States, they are not as mature as the kids in — in — in — living in the conditions, wartime conditions. Kids mature fast. You know, when you’re in danger, y-you don’t think about baseball, TV sets, and things at the time that was not existing. But we were seriously interested of what was going on. When I joined the underground — maybe that’s a subject later on —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — this was 1940 — ’42, I was — I was what, 12 - 13 years old.

segments.question: You were young.
segments.answer: I was young.

segments.question: You were young. You were young. Okay, so the day before, you remember going to the deli with your sister.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What about the day itself? When did you learn? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015
segments.answer: We learn the first, when we saw the German airplanes flying over, and the Polish anti-aircraft artillery opened the full blast, whatever was necessary to protect our skies, I saw the dogfights of the Polish P-11 fighter planes in the sky. The Messerschmitts were much faster, and they were metal planes. But the planes that Poland had, had a very [phone ringing][break]

segments.question: So you — you saw the Polish planes, yes.
segments.answer: The Polish planes. The anti-aircraft — actually, there was a heavy machine gun position near that Clement’s church, in their garden, you know, they set up near the church, because you know, the religious Germans would not maybe mount an attack somewhat close to the church. But this — this post was manned by the — by the Polish army, and the anti-aircraft was very effective.

segments.question: Were any of them shot down?
segments.answer: I saw, let’s say, smoke trails, three times. One was, I think, Polish airplane, and then the two Messerschmitts went down. The conflict that lasted from first of September til sixth of October, the losses that the Germans suffered in the air force — they say that the Polish air force was grounded and non-existing, on the contrary. I have a book written by Becker, a German writer, who said that first 16 days, there was a very effective strength of Polish air force. Pilots were very well trained in Deblin air academy. And these pilots that were fighting in 1939 over the Polish Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 skies, they escape through Romania, through France, to England. And they were part of the — part of the battle — Battle of Britain.

segments.question: So, in other words, did they become — did they set up the training for the RAF pilots, and for Polish pilots over — over Germany?
segments.answer: The RAF, yes, that was the — Doening(ph), General Doening(ph), the head of the RAF. He was very skeptical, because there was a language barrier, and actually, he finally, when he saw what the damages the Luftwaffe did to the British, he decided to accept the Polish contingent of air pilots, and there were two squadrons formed. Three or two, and three or through — three. Kosciuszko Squadron. I even have a poster that I can later on show you. These pilots — if you saw a movie, “Battle of Britain,” there were Poles, very brave, and we had the highest score, beating the Germans on equal basis, you know, because Spitfires and Hurricanes were equivalent to Messerschmitts. Or Dornier, or whatever they had, the bombing airplanes, the Heinkels and Dorniers, and all the weapons that Goering provided for — for the Operation Sea Lion, whatever it was, he wanted to put Britain on the — on her knees. And the fight was very, let’s say, effective. So the pilots, the pilots that left Poland, they put their talent to action in England, when they had better airplanes, but the spirit very strong. The — the British were a little skeptical, because of the language, and we were not so very obedient. We had our Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ~ January 27, 2015 style of fighting in the sky, and the guys really, when they attacked, th-th-the British squadron leader at that time, there was a Canadian by the name of Kent. He was trying to control the disobedience of Pole, how to attack the Germans, but the results were rather — very effective. Realize that the Poles in England, with 15 squadrons, four bomber squadrons. We accounted for almost 1000 German planes shot in the air, th-the dogfights. One thousand, that’s a big —

segments.question: That’s a lot.
segments.answer: — big score.

segments.question: That’s a lot.
segments.answer: The 303 was the Kosciuszko Squadron. And why we named the Kosciuszko Squadron was the story of Kosciuszko heard that we got as a rep — re-reprocity. See, the Poland regained her independence, thanks to President Wilson. And at that time Americans wanted to pay the — pay the dues for — for fighting, for independence of Poland from the Bolsheviks; this is the first World War. And 18 American pilots, Americans, they formed the squadrons that fought the Bolsheviks.

segments.question: Oh, really?
segments.answer: And they were the Kosciuszko Squadron.

segments.question: Oh, I see. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ~ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And Kosciuszko name for the bri — Battle of Britain was with the insignia of the same thing of Kosciuszko, with the American flag, with the two [indecipherable] like this, I show you later on —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — in that poster. But that was paid respect for the Poles for our, let’s say, contribution to the independence of the United States.

segments.question: Yes, yes.
segments.answer: That was now the General Pulaski that was, that died in Savanna, Georgia. The father of American cavalry. And Kosciuszko, the father of West Point. I don’t know if you ever visited West Point?

segments.question: I—I haven’t, but — and I didn’t know that he would have been the founder of it.
segments.answer: Yes, he started this whole thing, as a stronghold against the Brits.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And there’s a big bol — Kosciuszko monument in the square of the — and there are many — many artifacts, and remembrances. Jefferson was that —

segments.question: Yes, of course.
segments.answer: He called Kosciuszko as a — the son — the true son of freedom.

segments.question: I do know who Kosciuszko was, of course, but —
segments.answer: Yeah. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ~ January 27, 2015

segments.question: — that — but I didn’t know this about West Point.
segments.answer: Yeah, West Point.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That was acad — a military academy, yeah.

segments.question: Right, sure. Okay, that’s a far away from Warsaw, and September first —
segments.answer: Yes, okay, yes, I’m sorry for that [indecipherable] —

segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And then how did the following days unvel — unfold and develop, in those first few days of —
segments.answer: Few — few days of —

segments.question: — in Warsaw, and what do you see? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala * January 27, 2015
segments.answer: — let’s say — in eight — eight or ninth of September, the German forces were surrounding the city. Warsaw was defending herself til the 28" of September. No water, no ammunition, so that forced us to — to surrender.

segments.question: Okay, here’s my question, though: what was happening with your family?
segments.answer: My family, okay.

segments.question: I want to know what happened with you.
segments.answer: This — we — on the 11", I think, on the 11 of September, I saw the Germans’ planes coming over and making some white streaks in the sky, and let’s say a few hours later, a heavy artillery bombardment started.

segments.question: So you hadn't heard any bombs before? No bombs were falling on Warsaw —
segments.answer: No, there were bombs — bombs bombing was, but not the part that we lived in.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: That was the direct hit that they started attacking the complex, because the repair shops of these transportation company, they looked like hangars, you know —

segments.question: Aha, okay.
segments.answer: — buildings, and the other buildings were sort of industrial. So when they marked, the artillery barrage started.

segments.question: Okay. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala *° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And it was so powerful that the whole thing — we only were saving was our lives, that’s all, because there was such a quick, rapid involvement in flames, under the attack, that I remember we were trying to save one person that was locked behind the doors, and we were trying to break the lock to get to, because when we found it th-th-that a man had both legs cut off. So we tried to save him, but it was in vain. We saved one —

segments.question: I—I don’t — I don’t understand, what is it that you — I understand you’re saying that man had both — how did — who was he, and where was he?
segments.answer: No, he was a repairman or a watchman in that company that was in the — in the — in the repair shops, you know.

segments.question: Okay. And the — and the bomb fell, and the or —
segments.answer: The — the — the artillery shells were falling left and right. The char — the buildings were inflamed. And — and — and — and we were trying to save lives. People — wounded — wounded people, so I was running around, trying to find the rubber hoses from the gas ovens, to use as —

segments.question: Tourniquets.
segments.answer: — tourniquets to stop the bleeding. We were carrying some of the wounded people to the hospital next few blocks, on Plocka Street, in Wola. But whenever we delivered them to the hospital, most of them were — bled to death. So, we couldn’t Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 save them. But when the houses, our houses, our apartment were all destroyed. You know who came to our rescue?

segments.question: Who?
segments.answer: We had orphanage across the street, orphanage of Korczak’s. Korezak.

segments.question: Oh, Janusz Korezak?
segments.answer: Janusz Korezak. His real name was Goldsmith, I believe.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Janusz Korezak gave us a protection in his house, that was somehow saved. And I was in the basement. He was feeding me the oatmeals for a couple weeks.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: Korezak. I knew him personally, yeah.

segments.question: How did you know him? As a —
segments.answer: How did I know him?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: In — he provided shelter for us. I remember he was in Polish uniform with the — with the rank of lieutenant, I think. The — he was in the Polish armed forces, in the uniform, because as a reserve officer.

segments.question: Had you known him before this?
segments.answer: No, no — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: —no, no. We met during that disaster.

segments.question: So your own apartment was bombed out?
segments.answer: Yes. His house still stays there. There’s a monument of Janusz Korezak in the yard, in the courtyard.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] I have some pictures of the —

segments.question: Well, tell us, you know, for those who will not know, who was Janusz Korcezak?
segments.answer: Oh, Janusz Korezak was the educator and teacher, well-known in western Europe, how to develop a child’s, let’s say, spiritual background. And he was teaching the Polish schools about how to bring up the children the right way. He was a doctor by — by profession. He was very well-known among the Poles, and also abroad, as a writer, and teacher.

segments.question: What happened to him?
segments.answer: What happened to him. When — when the Germans build the ghetto, he was taken with the children — there was about 200 children —

segments.question: Were they Jewish?
segments.answer: Yes, m — Jewish, yes. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ~ January 27, 2015

segments.question: So this was a Jewish orphanage?
segments.answer: All Jewish orphanage, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was moved to Chiodna Street, that was a building where they accommodated them, and this was in the portion that I mentioned before, when the small ghetto was adjacent to the large ghetto through three, four blocks, between Zelazna and Wronia, along the Chlodna Street, Chtodna Street. So I remember, as child going to that trade school, we had the backpacks. We used to use our blouses and backpacks for food. When we bordered the streetcar that was going through that three blocks of both ghettoes, we used to empty our —

segments.question: Backpacks.
segments.answer: — backpacks, and — and whatever food we could share, we were throwing it on the street so the kids from the building actually were picking it up.

segments.question: So, in other words, they were allowed to go on the street. The streetcar — you couldn’t leave the streetcar, but you could throw things out the window.
segments.answer: Yes, yes, the — the police blew — policemen that were protecting people from getting off the streetcar, or getting on the streetcar, because streetcar didn’t stop in that segment, you know, it was going from the Towarowa Street, which was the — let’s say two blocks to Wronia, and then about four blocks to Zelazna. And this Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “" January 27, 2015 portion was off limits to the Aryans, and vice-a-versa. The Jews couldn’t board the — the streetcars to get out from ghetto.

segments.question: And did this streetcar operate throughout the — the whole time the ghetto was in existence?
segments.answer: Yes, the streetcars were going to through the main — main thoroughfares, through Warsaw, and through ghetto, with the — the streetcar, our streetcars, the Aryan side, used to have the numbers. The Jewish portion, they used to have the Star of David —

segments.question: I see, so they would —
segments.answer: — on that round —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — signal sign.

segments.question: So there were actually Jewish streetcars?
segments.answer: Let’s say manned by the Polish operators, but going through the ghetto.

segments.question: And only the ghetto.
segments.answer: Only to ghetto, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And after, let’s say, that Chiodna Street, when things got bad, the Korezak orphans were moved to Sienna Street, Sienna Street, which is close to the Palace Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015 of Science that Stalin gived. Even now when I visited Warsaw, there is a Korezak monument near the fountain, you know, as he’s embracing children.

segments.question: I see, but then — but the Stalin building wasn’t there yet, this is all before this. The — the building that — that you say was the gift of Stalin, wasn’t there at the time.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: This was before this.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: This was before that, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So, from there, from Sienna Street, where the monument of Korezak is located in Warsaw, the kids were taken, and he walked with the orphans to the Treblinka for gas — for being gassed.

segments.question: So that was —
segments.answer: Korezak died with these — with these orphans.

segments.question: I see. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala °* January 27, 2015
segments.answer: There is a Korezak Park here in Chicago, as a— as a memory of —
