segments.answer: There’s a book — there is a book written about that — I forgot the title of it, but it’s access to very many — many, many, let’s say publications on that subject of Korezak in that library, the Jewish library on Tlomackie Street, near — in the vicinity of that previous synagogue —

segments.question: I see. I see.
segments.answer: —in Warsaw. If you’re ever interested in this, go to Tlomackie Museum, maybe they relocated some of it to that new museum that’s on Nalewki(ph) Street, near the Umschlagplatz.

segments.question: Okay. So, how many people did Korezak take in after this bombing?
segments.answer: I would say there were about 200 kids, yes.

segments.question: I mean, that’s how many there were before the bo — Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Before that, yeah, yeah.

segments.question: And then, since — since the artillery fire, and your bi — your home was destroyed, how many did he take in? New people?
segments.answer: Oh, the refugees? I would say ma — my family was there, and maybe some three or four other groups — families that were in that basement.

segments.question: So you could have been about 40 people, or so?
segments.answer: I would say, yeah — about that, yeah, yeah.

segments.question: Okay. And you said you got to speak with him?
segments.answer: Oh, he was — he was — he was delivering the o — oatmeals, you know, I was exhausted from that fire and then that shock from the artillery bombings, so I was sort of shaken up to the point that he had to calm me down with — whenever he was bringing the hot oatmeal to me, he was almost feeding me, so I could eat, you know. So, he was very soft.

segments.question: Oh, really?
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah.

segments.question: Did he say anything to you?
segments.answer: Oh, he said, you look very, very tired to me, you look very tired, so I have to help you to rebuild your strength.

segments.question: That sounds great, very kind. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Because you know, during the siege of Warsaw that lasted 28 days, our food supplies were exhausted. The water was short, a shortage of water, and the resistance was strong, very strong. We defended Warsaw for so long, and the Germans admired the — the knighthood of the Polish army that I’m after. Because de-defending Warsaw was a guy by the name of Rommel, General Rommel, the Polish side. I don’t know if there was any connection of that Erwin Rommel in Africa, or Rommel General.

segments.question: How interesting.
segments.answer: Yeah, Rommel —

segments.question: And how tronic.
segments.answer: Yeah. Juliusz Rommel. And there was another general, Czuma, Czuma, [ think his son was here in Chicago for a while, but he returned to Poland. Czuma. Czuma, c-z-u-m-a, Czuma.

segments.question: So, where did you go after you were at this orphanage? You didn’t stay there forever? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala °° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: On the orphanage, what we did is, portion of the building that was not completely damaged, so to speak of, so we covered the windows that were all broken, the floor, the doors. We tried to rebuild whatever space was available.

segments.question: Did you return to your old apartment?
segments.answer: Ah, no, no, no.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Thi-This whole thing was collapsed. The next — next possession, next building which I mentioned to you, this was a portion of that was offices, portion were this mechanical shop, or textile shop and some chemical stuff that they were doing upstairs. Portion of the offices we converted to our, let’s say, primitive living quarters. No water. The windows we covered with whatever. We didn’t have plastic, but there was something very foggy that we covered too, because the winter of 1940 was so severe that — frost was so strong that the pigeons were falling off the balconies.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: Very severe winter, minus 40 centigrade, almost.

segments.question: That’s huge.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: That’s huge, for a place that’s not that far north. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And there we was — we were — let’s say, the Germans, when they entered the city, some of the squares they set up the salamanders, you know, they were salamanders, they were like a coke ovens, and they heated up so the people could — could warm themselves. And Wehrmacht at that time, they set up field kitchens — can you imagine, for the civilians. The Wehrmacht was behaving like a regular — regular army. No — no behavior like the SS, or — or — or the, let’s say gent — the — the field police. Later on when the secondary units came, the Wehrmacht left, you know, so there was a change in attitude toward the civilians.

segments.question: So, you move back across the street, and — and into one of the offices that now you converted —
segments.answer: I returned back to the next possession actually, that was adjacent to the area where we lived. After the fire, we rebuild it. I remember we had two rooms at the beginning, the whole family. And there was a family by the name of Bront(ph), Bront(ph). I think that was a — a German citizen, and his wife was Polish, Behrowska(ph), and they had a daughter, Danuta(ph). And I think this family, because of the German roots, they signed the volks — Volksliste. They sign up to be part of, let’s say that superior race. So they lived in the two — they displaced us from the two rooms, and they — we were moved to the single room. Four people, single Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "" January 27, 2015 room. So, they later on moved out from the area, into a special section of the city that was reserved for the Germans.

segments.question: I see, I see. Did they have children, or was this only a couple?
segments.answer: They’re a couple, they had one child, there was — that was Danuta(ph). And when she came to visit us during the occupation, she was that hio — the ha — Hitlerjugend, but she was the madel, the — the — the —

segments.question: Ah, Wundersdeutchen madels.
segments.answer: —madel. Wundersdeutches madel. Yeah, she came in uniform, and we couldn’t talk too much to her, even though they were — she was very befriended with my sister, going to the ballet school together.

segments.question: But things changed.
segments.answer: It’s changed, yes. Now, I remember when I walked in when they were occupying that two room apartment, I remember the Griffarts(ph) on the wall. You know the name Griffarts(ph)?

segments.question: No, what’s that?
segments.answer: Oh, the German staff officers used to call Hitler Griffarts(ph).

segments.question: Griffarts(ph)?
segments.answer: Griffarts(ph). This was abbreviation of — of griisste — griisste feldherr aller zeit. The — the — the greatest field Marshall of all times. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “° January 27, 2015

segments.question: Griffarts(ph).
segments.answer: Griffarts(ph), yeah.

segments.question: And was it a term of respect and endearment?
segments.answer: Well, you know, the Wehrmacht were — tha-that was endearment — I — I rather not, because later on Hitler acted like a strategist, because he had dreams, you know. So — so —

segments.question: You mean, like dreams at night?
segments.answer: At night, yeah —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — that he was trying to implement these dreams into the action, you know. Manstein — Manstein, his number one strategist on the eastern front, he had to listen to the fuehrer, you know. So the officers among themselves, from time to time they used the name —

segments.question: So they had a picture — okay, so, in their apartment, you — the — the Brandt(ph) family had Griffarts(ph) on the wall.
segments.answer: He had the fuehrer on the wall, so that — to us it was a shock.

segments.question: Groste Feldmarschall —
segments.answer: Feldherr aller zeit.

segments.question: So how did your lives then — I mean, they wer — ye — it was — your life was turned over because you lost your place to live, and Warsaw was now occupied by — by the German Wehrmacht, and soon — how did things develop? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala m January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Let’s say the control of the city — I think that was a Fisher, the — the governor of the city, because Frank was — Frank was in Krakow. Krakow was the head — ci — the main city of GG, government gubern —

segments.question: Gouvernement?
segments.answer: Gouvernement, yeah. General na gubernia(ph)

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And Warsaw was a city of transit for the Germans to the eastern front, one of the cities. So the character of the city was changed. A lot of military uniforms we ve seen in the streets everywhere, that they were occupying the best place to, let’s say, live and be treated. So most of the theaters, restaurants, were with the inscription, nur fiir Deutsche, for Germans only.

segments.question: I see. So Poles couldn’t go there.
segments.answer: So streetcars, even streetcars, you know, they had the platform, front platform on the streetcar there was nur fur Deutsche, only for Germans. Sometimes when there were too many, let’s say, attacks on the Germans, or too many of their side weapons disappeared, because in the crowd, the streetcar, many times, you know, the AK were cutting their holsters, and stealing their weapons, and so on, and so on. So they were changing the platform, sometimes in front, sometimes in the back. But this was strictly for Germans. And a city, as such, you know, was divided for the Aryans Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015 and the Jews. The ghetto was formed, the wall was built, and the minority of the Jews, which was the largest diaspora in the world; I think maybe more than in New York; so they were put into either small ghetto, or large ghettos. A small ghetto actually, delicately speaking, was reserved for the well-to-do —

segments.question: Oh really?
segments.answer: — Jews. Yes. And the large ghetto was — well, the Germans used the term lumpenproletariat.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Did you hear that one?

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Lumpenproletariat. So the poor Jews were in the large ghetto.

segments.question: So-
segments.answer: And, well, the annihilation of the Jewish race started right from the beginning, when they activated Treblinka, which was the closest crematorium, closest to Warsaw.

segments.question: So, there was a gas chamber as well as a crematorium?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. I'd like to focus a little bit more precisely on what changes did you see, and what changes happened within your family? So let’s — let’s focus on that. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala i January 27, 2015
segments.answer: It’s — okay, my sister was working for a food — food — food factory, and my father, as I mentioned, because of his knowledge of German language, he was used as a interpreter.

segments.question: When you say your sister was working for a food factory, was this now something under German control?
segments.answer: Yes, yes. Most of the Polish industry, which was in the city, and the workshops and the — all kind of places where they could use for the war machinery for the Third Reich —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — they immediately activated that, an-and they were trying to give some kind of a priority to produce the machinery of war. Like for instance, that building nearby, what we lived in, the section that there were offices converted to apartments. Now, this portion of the building, the — what was saved after the bombardment, they repaired whatever they could, but the basement and the first floor, what they were doing, they were building field kitchens, you know, just like the first World War, that was on wheels. All these containers and they were cooking the meals for the army. So —

segments.question: Oh, I see.
segments.answer: Yeah, so this was a place, pretty active. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala m January 27, 2015

segments.question: So, 1t meant the equipment that — that cooked the food was being manufactured there.
segments.answer: Manufactured there, yes, by the Poles. And the production was for the Wehrmacht. I remember a visit one day that — I don’t know whether he was a Reichsdeutsche or Volksdeutsche. I think he must have been Reichsdeutsche because he had that Tyrolean hat with the little —

segments.question: Feather?
segments.answer: — brush.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Feathers. And he came over, visited. He came in a Skoda, Skoda, that was Czech car, very nice car. And he inspected the facilities, you know.

segments.question: Was this a— a—a person in a uniform, or in civilian —
segments.answer: No, he was a— a~—a private — private — a civilian uniform, yeah, civilian uniform.

segments.question: Uh-huh. So was the — so was the — was this production facility owned by — beca — was it still private? In private hands, but German hands?
segments.answer: I would say yes. I didn’t see any in uniform, any people in uniform. There was the guy that came over a couple times, you know, to inspect the facility, and see what there is — the production rate, or whatever. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala . January 27, 2015

segments.question: Mm-hm. Did you know that — if he was a chief or something?
segments.answer: I would say so, because he had that round sign — badge of Reichsdeutsche —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — you know, they used to have these badges on their lap —

segments.question: Lapel.
segments.answer: Yeah, patel — yeah, that’s — it was — it — it looked like a Ebermensch(ph).

segments.question: An tibermensch, yeah.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Now, when you said that those apartments had been conver — those offices were converted into apartments, and at first you had the two room one, and then you were — your family was pushed out into a one room, what kind of kitchen facilities were there?
segments.answer: You know, we — we sometimes improvised things as we need. So I remember my father built his own little oven, connected to the stack, to the chimney, and we were cooking right on two — two — let’s say two burners, not burners, but fire [indecipherable] what we had that was something, a hotplate like. So this was the part, and the sanitary facilities, they were using some toilets that were left, you know, with —

segments.question: From the office. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala mc January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yeah —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — of the office, so the primitive and very s-simple way, and the — the idea was to survive, so we did not complain too much.

segments.question: What about taking a bath?
segments.answer: Heating — hm?

segments.question: What about taking a bath, and heating? How did you handle those things?
segments.answer: This — heating, we were boiling the water, you know —

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: — in that little stove that we had. The washing facilities, there used to be a public — the public shower stations in the city, so we utilized these.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But then we were heating the water in some tub, you know, and then washing ourselves the best we could.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There was a lack of everything, you know. Soap was scarcity, paper was a scarcity. Bread tha-that was made for the Poles. Sometimes we were laughing that that bread was just like a — like a — like a board, not properly baked in the — in — in — in enough time to make it edible, to make it edible. They didn’t use the flour, they Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015 used the sawdust underneath in the ovens, you know, so — so this was a substitute. Everything was ersatz.

segments.question: Substitute, yes.
segments.answer: Substitute. Ersatz. That’s a — the bread, the basic stuff, staple. The marmalade was made out of beets, sweetened up with saccharin. You know, it was the artificial sweetener. And that thing, you could eat as much as you wanted, but the next day the thing was fermented and was growing. You always had a full — full jar. So meat was only on the black market — black market, you know, so the ingenious Poles were going to the countryside to bring food. The Germans intercepted — most of the railroad stations they were intercepting in order to take that food away from them. But food; meat, butter, you know, these were things very difficult to obtain.

segments.question: And they were forbidden?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes. Schwarzmarkt is what they call it, the black market, was a no-no.

segments.question: Well, here’s —
segments.answer: The Germans were setting up patrols and — and — and stopping the trains before this destination, and — and — and getting the people, sorting them out, and checking what kind of food they bringing.

segments.question: Okay. I want to just make sure that I understand it properly. There was rationing, yes? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ® January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There was rationing. We —

segments.question: And there was rationing so that you could get only a certain amount of any kind of food, but was it actually so that certain foods were forbidden to even have, whether the e — for example, if it’s eggs, or butter, or meat. I-Is it that it’s not forbidden if you have it in your home, that it’s forbidden to bring it there? Ho-How did that work?
segments.answer: Let’s see, it was forbidden to — meat, especially meat, you know. But eggs you could buy on the bla — black market; flour and butter, you know. Whatever the people could smuggle in from the countryside, that was done. But not all these, let’s say attempts, were successful. The Germans were intercepting and taking away from the people.

segments.question: Okay. So —
segments.answer: So even they joked that sometimes as — a pig was smuggled into the city. But how it was smuggled? Because it was dressed up in a human suit, you know, where the snout was all covered up with bandages, you know, and the — th-they — the German patrol was told that this was a sick man going to Warsaw hospital; suddenly there was a pig. Women were — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015

segments.question: Was that actually true?
segments.answer: Yes, yes. There were many, many different ways of how to outwit the Germans, for the sake of survival. Things were very risky, but still they had to be played.

segments.question: So you are at — in 1939, you’re a 10 year old boy.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: You go through the winter of 1940, and di — did your sister and yourself ever refer to that conversation that you had about gee, it would be interesting to see what war was like, after you actually felt it?
segments.answer: Yes, many a times said now, we are experiencing this unfortunate exchange of thoughts that we had just before the war started. Because the occupation was cruel, very cruel. And we were treated as sub-humans.

segments.question: Did you — how did you personally experience that kind of treatment?
segments.answer: How did I experience that kind of treatment? First, as I said, the streetcars were separated for Germans, and for the Poles.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: The s — on the sidewalks very often, we had to leave room as the Germans were passing by for them. And the lines for food in our, let’s say, stores, were long, people were waiting, sometimes for nothing. The German stores, there was a company my — Mynell(ph) — Mynell(ph), that was for Germans, where they could Interview with Thaddeus Gubala i January 27, 2015 buy anything they wanted; butter, eggs, meat. Everything just for the Germans, separated from the Polish.

segments.question: Were there German civilians?
segments.answer: Yes. During the heavy bombing of Reich, the — Germany wen — was bombed. Many Germans, to save their lives, they were moving. Let’s say members of the families, they were moving into Warsaw to live, and certain parts of the city were reserved for a German population. The better sides, undestroyed, and — was provided for the German families, Reichsdeutsche that came from the — from the Reich.

segments.question: So, does that mean towards — clo — closer towards the second part of the war? If you're saying it’s when Germany itself was being bombed, or —
segments.answer: Well, the mass — mass bombing, you know, it started where the Americans declared war, when was this, 19 —

segments.question: Forty-four, so that’s late.
segments.answer: Forty-three, I believed it.

segments.question: No, the Americans started in — June 6", 1944 was the invasion of Normandy.
segments.answer: Normandy? Oh, but I am speaking of bombing of Germany was already — I think the —

segments.question: Underway? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: — American air force was already in England prior to that day.

segments.question: Oh, that could very well be.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: That could very well be.
segments.answer: And — and the — Harris, what they call General Harris, the bomber — there’s a monument in London of Harris.

segments.question: Well, but my point is — my — my question is, did these civilians, were they were from the very beginning —
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: — in Warsaw? They appeared later?
segments.answer: No, they appeared later.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Later, yes.

segments.question: So, in the beginning the Germans that you saw were military people, were all somehow or other connected with the war effort?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay. Did you see any — you mentioned during the shelling of the artillery, when the factory that — in your home was — was destroyed, that people died, were killed as a result of this artillery fire. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ia January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Did you ever see anybody el — did you ever see anybody treated violently on the street? Did you ever see any corpses on the roads?
segments.answer: No, not violently in the street, there was no scene like this. But there were times where the Germans, let’s say, separated certain parts of the street, or streetcars that were in, in order to kidnap the people for work in the Reich. So these things were very frequent.

segments.question: And you saw these things.
segments.answer: Yes, I was part of it. That’s a scene that I remember. One of my colleagues, he had a pistol on him, and when the Germans stopped, you know, he was so upset that he started sweating, you know. And there was an older lady, say 80 - 85, she look at that young fellow, and she open her purse, you know. So he put the gun —

segments.question: In her purse.
segments.answer: — into her purse, she close it. The Germans didn’t attack her, you know, didn’t question her at all. And the boys —

segments.question: But they searched him.
segments.answer: — he save his — she saved his life. And — and the spirit, and — and the brotherhood among the Poles in Warsaw was unusually unique and — and good, from the sense Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ia January 27, 2015 that we stood for each other until the end. And we knew that the end is coming for all of us, one way or the other, so we stuck together. There was a —

segments.question: And that’s — that’s unusual.
segments.answer: Yeah. For [indecipherable] yes, yes. There were — there were cases, you know, like schmeil(ph) shovnik(ph), you heard that expression?

segments.question: Tell me what this is.
segments.answer: Schmeil(ph) shovnik(ph) were the people that, for instance, when the Jews were vacating some areas in Warsaw, these guys were sort of acting against them.

segments.question: How”
segments.answer: Anti-Semitism, by e-even — even in the cemetery, you know, when they saw the buried bodies, you know, so they were hunting for people buried, for gold teeth, and things like that.

segments.question: So they were — they were actually going through corpses to be able to rob them of whatever —
segments.answer: Yes. These were cases, yes. And th-the underground government, when they saw certain peoples, the squealers, or some informers, they used to issue the death sentences, and AK was executing these people.

segments.question: Now, you — you — did you know all this as that 10 or 12 year old boy, walking the streets? I want to get back to this child. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ™ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: I was a member — okay, I was a member, I joined the underground when I was 12. In 1942, I was sworn in in Schweidel, the suburb, you know, very nice forest there. I was sworn in into paramilitary organization, which was — pre-war, it was the Boy Scout movement.

segments.question: So tell me how did that happen? Did you find them, or did they find you?
segments.answer: No, they found me, I think. I had two good teachers, you know. Casimira(ph) Bye(ph) and Janina(ph) Guretsky(ph). They were observing me at school, and my behavior, and the way they trusted me. And there was a third teacher, that was Mrs. Bernisz(ph). She was of German descent. And they accosted me, and they ask me if I would be interested to work in the underground. So, I sign up, I was sworn in in 1942, and the rest of the years of occupation, I was a member of the Home Army, Polish Home Army, with the sign of, as you can see, that anchor, PW, which stands of Polska Walczaca, I don’t know, the fighting Poland.

segments.question: The fighting Poland?
segments.answer: Yes. This was a sign repeated many places, on monuments —

segments.question: Can — excuse me. Can we focus in on that please? On the — what’s on his — on his tie?
segments.answer: Oh, this one is here.

segments.question: Yeah. So it’s — it has an anchor, and it has — Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala a January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And W.

segments.question: And — and a di—
segments.answer: P for Poland, and W for Walezaca, which means fighting.

segments.question: Okay, Walezaca.
segments.answer: Yeah. Krahelska was the designer, one of the soldiers that died the first day of uprising was Krystyna Krahelska. She designed that —

segments.question: That sign. The insignia.
segments.answer: That sign, and that remained with us, yeah.

segments.question: Did your parents know any of what you were going to be doing, or — or —
segments.answer: Especially when I was coming — you know, there was a police hour in Warsaw, eight o’clock.

segments.question: Curfew.
segments.answer: Curfew, yes, that people stopped in the street without proper documents, they were arrested, and if they didn’t respond to, let’s say a [indecipherable] they were shot. After many a times, I was coming home, and there was a discussion, you know, and finally they gave up, you know, because I couldn’t do — they couldn’t punish me anymore. So I was disappearing for late hours to do my duties, which were — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "° January 27, 2015

segments.question: So — I’m going to interrupt right here. You’re saying that you would come home after eight o’clock, and your parents would be upset?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And they would say —
segments.answer: Where were you?

segments.question: — where were you? And did they — did you tell them?
segments.answer: They sensed something, yes, they did sense something, that I was doing all kind of things that would be penalized by death.

segments.question: And did they ever address those risks?
segments.answer: The way — the way we lived, and the feeling we had toward the occupiers, they did not forbade my activity, no.

segments.question: Your mother — you said your father was working as an interpreter at the Ostbahn.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Now, what was your mother doing, was she ki — still in that cafeteria?
segments.answer: Sh— no, no, there was no more of — that was burned out place, and she was just a housewife, you know, fighting to prepare a meal for us.

segments.question: Not easy.
segments.answer: Here and there, every day. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015

segments.question: Yeah, not easy.
segments.answer: Whatever was available.

segments.question: What did you usually eat?
segments.answer: Oh, let’s say, for school, sandwich. We had that — that bread, which we called sort of a — like a pumpernickel bread. Two slices that were soaked 1n artificial coffee made out of grain, regular grain. Put some sugar on top of it, put these things together, and that was my sandwich for school.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: Or, sometimes the onion that was fried in some schmaltz, lard, and this was sort of a spread —

segments.question: Onto the —
segments.answer: — for the sandwich. Meat was a scarcity, scarcity. And let’s say sometimes the Ostbahn, they had the cafeterias where my mother could get the soup for us.

segments.question: So your father would bring it back, or —
segments.answer: No, my mother used to walk to there and she had the document that she was wife of the employee of the Ostbahn, and she was bringing the soup home.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But I’m speaking of soup.

segments.question: I know. I know. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "= January 27, 2015
segments.answer: But the pota — piece of potato was a surprise. And piece of meat, you know, unseen. So this was a starvation diet.

segments.question: And you said your sister worked in a food production factory —
segments.answer: Yes, be —

segments.question: — or place, or something. So what was that all about?
segments.answer: The food was actually for us, for the Poles. That was not for the production, for the Germans, was strictly controlled by — by the Germans, you know, so they — they were very careful. Let’s say they were confiscating the cattle and the — and all the things, but the processing of that was made by — by them.

segments.question: Okay. So, your sister worked. What kind of food was she producing?
segments.answer: I think this was like marmalades, and all kind of preserves, fruit preserves. No — other, let’s say preserves. They were — made, you know, pickling the cucumbers, or — or pickles. And that was the simpl — simple — simple food like this, you know.

segments.question: And did she ever bring any of that home?
segments.answer: Oh, she — they put that was that, let’s say, instead of payment, you know, they used to give something for the employees. Like my father used to get the alcohol, or coal — coal for burning in the stove. Or sometimes he was getting a — a bread, or mar-margarine. Artificial butter. So these things that he could get from the — from his superiors, you know. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala i January 27, 2015

segments.question: So, instead of — instead of money, sometimes his — he was paid in —
segments.answer: That was like a premium. Sort of a supplement to — to — to — to —

segments.question: To the salary.
segments.answer: — to mediocre salaries. Because this money what the Germans issued had no purchasing power.

segments.question: Ah.
segments.answer: Like for instance, if you went for the black market to buy food in the country. The farmers used to accept only the pre-war money, which was silver coins. Silver coins, you know, the tens ztotys, five zlotys, two zlotys. They were silver. I-I think at about 60 or 70 percent pure silver. So they knew the metal value, and they were selling food for this kind of bouillon.

segments.question: I see. Rather — and rather than the —
segments.answer: Than accepting the paper money issued by the Germans, which had no — it was good for the General na gubernia(ph) to — to — to buy some stuff on the black market, but the farmers, they were very skeptical about the paper money.

segments.question: Okay. Krystyna(ph) herself, was she involved in any underground activities?
segments.answer: Who?

segments.question: Your sister. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015
segments.answer: My sister? I— she knew something about it. Very often, you know, th — sh-she didn’t show up on time home, it seemed to me, but everything was enveloped in secrecy. We couldn’t operate with the names, we were using only nom de guerre.

segments.question: Mm-hm, what was yours?
segments.answer: Tabacca(ph).

segments.question: So your pseudonym was Tabacca(ph)?
segments.answer: Tabacca(ph). And then when there was some kind of a [indecipherable] which we used to call when the Germans discovered some — somebody that was squealing, and we were in danger of being discovered, I was changed to Zbeek(ph) Enrysh(ph).

segments.question: Zbeek(ph)?
segments.answer: Zbeek(ph) Enrysh(ph).

segments.question: Enrysh(ph).
segments.answer: Fox — and Zbeek(ph) was [indecipherable] too —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — you know, so I change, but normally I am using that Tabacca(ph) as a —

segments.question: As a pseudonym.
segments.answer: —my nom de guerre, yeah. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala " January 27, 2015

segments.question: Yeah. So, your father worked there, your sister worked in the food production place, your mother stayed at home and tried to find some way of making meals.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Did your father ever t-tell stories of what he would see at the Ostbahn? What kind of things he would be translating?
segments.answer: When — he often told me about the German trains coming from the eastern front. He said that he saw some kwerp — corpses. I mean, the people without legs, you know, frozen noses, ears. But they were running through the tracks that were separated by some kind of partition, so the civilians wouldn’t see them. But he said that casualties were coming from the eastern front, yes.

segments.question: So he could see these things and he talked about them?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yeah. And did he work with one particular German if — in — official in particular, or with many?
segments.answer: I think with many, because the administration of the railroad was in many hands, you know, but the chief honcho, I don’t even know who —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — who — who that guy was. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015

segments.question: And what would be the sort of things — he — was he a sort of like an in — in between the — the German bosses and the other workers? Is this where his translation skills were used, for them to translate orders? Or was it in different capacities?
segments.answer: He was translating because there were many Poles employed that didn’t speak German. But the work assignments that were, let’s say, by the Germans to direct certain squads of people to do this kind of work, [indecipherable] repairs, or the — what they call, the platform repairs, or — or is — cleaning up the stations, you know. So he was always called in as a interpreter.

segments.question: And do you think that he might have been involved in underground work?
segments.answer: I—I don’t think so. Maybe he was accosted by some people, but I don’t think that he was — he was aware of that I was doing, toward the end, but I don’t think he was part of it. He, let’s say, cooperated, if there was some assignment to report, yes. But I don’t think that he was fully sworn in, an-and — and — and working for the — for the underground. Let’s say Poles were all members of the underground. We were all, let’s say, sympathetic to the people that were actually the activists, you know, and the civilians were cooperating every time there was a situation, a dangerous situation, so they did help.

segments.question: Like the lady who opened her purse for the gun. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yeah, yeah. They say with that inscription, and I said nur fur Deutsche, we played the joke on Germans, because somehow the buchhandlung, there was some

segments.question: A bookstore.
segments.answer: — bookstore, in the German part of the ci-city, we bought a lot of these opaski, what was this? Armbands.

segments.question: The armbands, mm-hm.
segments.answer: Armbands, nur fur Deutsche, you know. And then we started putting in on the lampposts, telegraph posts, everything that was vertically up, you know, we put these things around, nur fur Deutsche. And they caught that thing after a while, and that was repercussions.

segments.question: Oh, really?
segments.answer: Just like repercussions was — the Germans used the sign of victory. The Pilsudski square in center of Warsaw, that’s where the tomb of unknown soldier is located. It still exists, partially, the uprising — survived the siege of 1939. There are only three or four columns. If you’ve been in Warsaw, maybe you saw it, the tomb of unknown soldier. Anyway, this was Pilsudski square. When Hitler came to Warsaw for the victory parade, as a gift they changed the name of many streets to German sounding names, and this was changed to Adolf Hitlerplatz. And in front Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015 of Poniatowski monument, they put a big sign of Victoria, and that victory sign underneath was Deutschland siegt am allen fronten.

segments.question: Okay, Germany is victorious on all fronts.
segments.answer: On all the fronts. The word siegt, we changed S to L, and the sos — Deutschland liegt am allen fronten.

segments.question: So that mean — allen fronten.
segments.answer: You know, this — this was a very —

segments.question: And how would you translate that?
segments.answer: The German lies on all the fronts. You know, flat. So this, they didn’t like it at all, because many places they had Deutschland siegt am allen fronten. And there were propaganda signs by Dr. Goebbels, even showing a Polish soldier wounded, and Churchill, and the Polish soldier is saying, England, this is your deed. I don’t know if you saw it in some of the books.

segments.question: No. So — oh the — so the fact —
segments.answer: That the guilt — the guilt lies in engl — with England, you know, that —

segments.question: That Poland is 0 — okay.
segments.answer: — they are guilty of — of our suffering, and so on. There was tremendous shock, the time I — that was 1943, around the springtime, March or — March, I think. There was mutual agreement between Poland — let’s say the government, Polish Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ° January 27, 2015 government in exile in England, Sikorski, with ma — with the Russians, fighting against common enemy.

segments.question: Correct.
segments.answer: But, when there was Katyn discovery, what happened is that the Germans advanced, and they stop at Smolensk, Charkow. They found this massive graves — graves, Polish graves. These were places of execution of the Polish officers that were captured during that attack on the 17" of March.

segments.question: September.
segments.answer: I mean, 17" of September, 1939, when they stabbed us in the back.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: They deported million and a half Poles to Siberia, and they separated the military personnel to be, let’s say, kept in the different camps. Out of this they selected the officers. The officers were the officers of reserves, so there were, you know, lawyers, doctors, professional officers and all kind of intelligentsia that was part of that 200-some 20 prisoners of war that these Russians captured. Out of this they selected the officers, and they were executed in Katyn.

segments.question: So you’re talking 220,000?
segments.answer: Two hundred twenty military personnel.

segments.question: Okay. Only 220 — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "° January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Thousand, out of which —

segments.question: A tow — thousand, mm-hm.
segments.answer: — they selected the —

segments.question: The officers.
segments.answer: The officers, and so on. They —

segments.question: So what happened when the graves were discovered? How 1s that received in Warsaw’?
segments.answer: As the Germans advanced, and they discovered — immediately the Russian propaganda was saying that the Germans did it, you know, and they tried to blame the Russians for this. The Germans, to prove the case, they have asked the higher ranking officers, British, French, and then whoever was there from the western European POW camps, and they form a commission. And this commission was joined by the Red Cross, and they all went to the passive disc — discovery of these big, massive graves, and they selected the caliber of the guns that they were using to shoot them in the back —

segments.question: Okay, I want to make sure I understand. They selected not only th — they asked not only the international Red Cross, but their own prisoners of war that they had captured —
segments.answer: Yes. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Thaddeus Gubala "t January 27, 2015

segments.question: They formed a commission from some of these selected people —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — who were prisoners themselves, to go to the site of the mass graves —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — and do what?
segments.answer: Exhume the bodies. Check, you know, some of the insignias, dog tags, and the — the — the bullets that normally they found the skulls with the hole in the back, because the prisoners were tied in the back, walked into the room, and shot by the NKVD —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — in the back of their heads.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So this was a shock for me, when I walked into classroom, and I saw my teacher crying, Mrs. Bernisz(ph).

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Or Umlaut.

segments.question: Or Umlaut.
segments.answer: [indecipherable]

segments.question: Bernisz(ph), yeah. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Bernisz(ph), you know. Her brother, Lieutenant Bernisz(ph), a Polish lieutenant — she admitted that she was of German descent, even for generations in — in Warsaw. So she says — she was crying, you know, and I ask her now, why do you cry ma’am? What happened? You know, she just simply pushed a Red Cross card, a notification postal card to me, and then I ripped it over, and I looked at this, and that was his name listed among the bodies exhumed from that mass grave.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: And this changed entirely, the diplomatic relations with the Polish government in exile. They were broken, these relations were broken, and the Russians ignored the free legal Polish government. They said that this is not true, the Germans did it, and we were siding with the fascists, you know. Th-The — the regular way of the Russian lies that are — even now you can s — listen to [indecipherable] and — and — and — and see how nicely he forms certain ways of how to do the right thing the Russian way.

segments.question: I see. Let’s go back to these events. So people discovered that — Warsaw begins to discover that these missing officers have been murdered by the rus — the Soviet forces.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: You find out in a very personal way, through your teacher. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ” January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Teacher, yes.

segments.question: How did it — how did people find out in general abou — was this something that the Germans were — were broadcasting?
segments.answer: Well, they were the — they were drumming it up. Germans were drumming it up, and the situation was even getting worse and worse, because the Polish formations of soldiers in Russia, under the command of General Anders —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — there was a situation when Sikorski met with Stalin and all the other big brass, Russian brass in — in — in Moscow, I think, and he asked about, where are the Polish officers? Because when we formed these units, Polish units to fight the Germans, where are the officers? And the Russians responded by saying, you know, they were somewhere in Manchuria and they run away. They escape from the captivity. They never admitted — they — you know when they admitted? When — I forgot his name, that Russian prior to Gorbachev, ye — ye — yench —

segments.question: Oh, prior to Gorbachev?
segments.answer: Gorbach — yelchin — yelchin —

segments.question: Yeltsin was after Gorbachev.
segments.answer: After Gorbachev?

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 100 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Prior to Gorbachev was Chernenko.
segments.answer: Chernenko?

segments.question: And then was Andropov.
segments.answer: No, one of them, I think Yeltsin was the one who admitted for the first time that this was the NKVD job, that what they did to the Polish officers.

segments.question: So we’re talking well over 50 years later.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yes. And — and — and Gorbachev admitted too, and he sealed off that this was the Russian doing.

segments.question: Okay. Your — let’s talk a little bit about your activities. Your e — inducted formally into the Home Army at the ripe old age of 12 - 13?
segments.answer: Twelve —

segments.question: Twelve?
segments.answer: — 13, yeah.

segments.question: And what was your involvement? Tell us about that.
segments.answer: My involvement — when I was sworn in, we were paramilitary because of the age, you know. There was Gray Ranks, Szare Szeregi we used to call Polish SS. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 101 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 You know, Szare Szeregi, Gray Ranks. That was sort of divided by age, you know, Zawiszacy were the youngest ones, which was a part of it. That was from, let’s say, 12 to about 15. And then Skoly Bojowe, the — the military schools, were from, let’s say 15 - 16, up to about 18. And then was — third group was the gr — Grupa Sztrumowa, the storming groups. These were guys 18 and up. That was a full military preparations, they were train in the forests for military action, and that military action was called the tempest — zboze tempest. And they were fully military organization. The lower group —

segments.question: So you’re saying there were — there were three different categories.
segments.answer: Three different categories guided by age. So let’s say the Skoly Bojowe, some guys were lying their age to join, you know, to be more active in the more advanced group, let’s say, Skoly Bojowe. So they pretended they are different —

segments.question: They’re older.
segments.answer: They’re olders, you know, the husky one. I was always small — small and puny, so I couldn’t even pretend that, so — anyway, they put me in that Szare Szeregi, and they put me in the platoon one, and this was the squad of yul — the regina(ph) yulka(ph). That was in [indecipherable] — what our activities were. So we were sabotaging the German vehicles as much as we could, you know. Even methods like — the Germans used the artificial fuel, gasholz. Gasholz was almost a—a—a-—a 102 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 [indecipherable] on a car, mounted, where they were using hardwood to — to — to burn, and form the methane gas that was actually the propelling —

segments.question: Agent.
segments.answer: — energy of the cars. So there was an air intake, and we used to put potatoes into the air intake and that thing would die. We put sugar into tanks, then the Germans introduced [indecipherable]

segments.question: But aren’t these — we — then — then, but these are deficit items, the potatoes, and the sugar.
segments.answer: Yes, yes, they were deficit items, but necessary. So they were sacrificed.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And then we were using all kind of propaganda posters to counteract the German propaganda posters. Like, for instance, the mysterious death of General Sikorski in Gibraltar. When General Sikorski was visiting Polish troops in the Near East, le — Lebanon, Palestine at that time, he was on the way back to London, and they made a stop in Gibraltar. You know the Gibraltar Straights?

segments.question: Yes, sure, sure.
segments.answer: Africa continent —

segments.question: Sure, sure. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 103 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: — you know, European? So, there was a mysterious death that the plane landed in the water, because the steering mechanism didn’t work.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Puzzling — puzzling item was that at that time the governor of that British base was Philby. You heard of Philby?

segments.question: Kim Philby.
segments.answer: Kim Philby. That was an agent, a communist. He was buried as a brigadier general of NK VD. This — this guy was actually — Philby was the secret agent allowed to — to have access to th-the top secrets of American state.

segments.question: Well, MI6.
segments.answer: Ducas — yes.

segments.question: Yes, MI6 is —
segments.answer: MI6 is a British —

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: — but I mean, the CIA or whatever, we had the security system here in the United States. Him —

segments.question: It wasn’t the CIA yet, but it was the — during the war —
segments.answer: SOS?

segments.question: OSS. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 104 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: OSS, yes.

segments.question: OSS.
segments.answer: So this was a very mysterious death, and he was buried in the — in the — in — the only guy that survived was pilot, Prchal — Prchal?

segments.question: Prchal.
segments.answer: Prchal. He was a Czech pilot.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: The plane was a Liberator, I think, and when that thing ended up in water, most of these — even daughter of General Sikorski, and some liaison officers, British officers died. So the only survivor was Prchal.

segments.question: Okay, and this is what year?
segments.answer: This was, I think fort — July °43.

segments.question: All right. And so how did that show up in the propaganda in Warsaw” So, how
segments.answer: How these things here, the wa — the — the posters were printed with the mysterious death and tragic death of our leader. How the thing was, I think, the BBC.

segments.question: Mm-hm. And so you would — the po — 105 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And we were posting this — let’s see, there was sign about what, 15 inches by 12 inches, you know, with the inscription, General Sikorski tragic death in Gibraltar and so on. We were posting in on any streets, main streets in Warsaw, to notify the public of what happened, you know. Not all had the access to — to BBC reports.

segments.question: Did you have a radio at home?
segments.answer: I had a crystal radio, you know, something.

segments.question: What’s a crystal radio?
segments.answer: Crystal radio di — was some kind of a magnetic stuff, with the earphones, that you could pick some of the waves, you know, from the air.

segments.question: So, you’d have an earphone —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: — a-— you'd have earphones on —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: — and then you’d have some sort of — what did it look like?
segments.answer: It was — look like a cr — a crystal, a metallic crystal, silver dots in it. But that was a poor reception.

segments.question: So, but it — it wasn’t even a box, it was just like a little knob, or something like that. 106 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Knob, yeah. But friends of ours that we used to go and visit, they had their radio in the big heating — heating ovens.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Heating ovens. That the radio was mounted in the back, and at night we used to listen to the BBC program. And you know, there was a special section in AK that was, let’s say, printing out on the basis of true news, because the German news were always partial on protecting the German side, and they never admitted their —

segments.question: Weaknesses.
segments.answer: — what was mistakes and —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — and things like that. They were always trying to minimize their losses, and maximize they — whatever they needed to — to — to tell us to bra — break the morale of the occu — occupied nations.

segments.question: So your — so you would be sabotaging the cars —
segments.answer: Sabotaging the cars, and then a second assignment was that, since there were two main bridge — two main bridges across the Vistula River to the eastern front, our assignment was to stay at hidden places, and mark and count the equipment, the armaments that went over the bridge. Tanks, armor cars, any cars, any guns, anything that was on wheels. So we used to have charts and mark these things to 107 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 send later on to our headquarters, which in turn sent it over to — to London. That was very useful, because the Brits knew, you know, what strength actually, the Germans are sending to the eastern front, that this was a sign to us on two bridges; Poniatowski bridge, and Kierbedzia bridge. So very often my duty was to be on the observing observer’s point.

segments.question: So, until you mentioned this, I figured most of those things that you would be doing, you’d have to do in the evenings, when that — when night fell.
segments.answer: Not in the beginning. We had these garbage — little garbage carts —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — you know, that there sometimes were — tilted them over. And under the cover, we were sitting there and doing all kind of dangerous markings in the different charts to — to counter the — the — the pieces that were across the bridge.

segments.question: I see, so in the — in the daytime you would observe —
segments.answer: After the police hours, at night, wi — you know, daytime, sure, we were doing this something by hearts, you know, watching and sitting on the curb of the sidewalk, you know, watching —

segments.question: Just like that.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: Okay. 108 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Watching this. And what else did we do dirty for the Germans.

segments.question: For the Home Army.
segments.answer: This was — you know, we were very critical of people going to — to — to movie theaters, and we had a saying, tylko Swinie siedac w kinie.

segments.question: What does that mean?
segments.answer: Only the pigs sitting in the movie theaters.

segments.question: And why would that be?
segments.answer: We used to — yeah, we used to put the name with the tar, you know, on the — on the entrance to the theaters. And that worked.

segments.question: But why would — why would that be —
segments.answer: [indecipherable] the money that was spent by the Poles that went to the armaments of the — this was government — the German government controlled.

segments.question: I see, so —I see. So it wasn’t that people wanted to have some relief, an-and see some sort of fantasy and escape from reality, 1t was because it was a way of helping the economy.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: The German economy.
segments.answer: Yes. There was another scene that I remember. See, they set up — when the war started, the Barbarossa Operation started, there was a big empty square right by 109 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 the central railroad station, so the Germans built a big screen to show their victorious march, drang nach osten, push to the east. The Barbarossa Operation, they were showing.

segments.question: So that’s June 1941, mm-hm.
segments.answer: Yes. They were showing, you know, the [indecipherable] Krakow, all the areas that were taken away from the Soviets, they were taking Russian prisoners by thousands, by thousands. And — and — and the Russians were giving up. They didn’t have the spirit, they didn’t have the good officers at that time. Why they didn’t have the good officers? Because the officers were chistka. You know what a chistka is?

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: The — Stalin in 1935 noticed that there were some kind of plot to — that they were trying to —

segments.question: Overthrow him.
segments.answer: — overthrow him. And this was among the Russian officers.

segments.question: Was it really a plot, or did he think it was a plot?
segments.answer: There was something that the Stalin was so upset, that he immediately ordered them to be put behind the bars, and many of them were eliminated. There was this case, and also — what else they — they were trying? Oh see, there was a lack of a — of 110 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 a higher command among the Russians at the time when the German were pushing forward.

segments.question: Okay, so it meant — it meant that in Warsaw, you’d have these big screens up, and — and you — and people would see —
segments.answer: At the central station, yes —

segments.question: And people would see?
segments.answer: Ye — they — you know, people were curious always, you know, when they saw the —

segments.question: So it was like an open movie theater?
segments.answer: Like an open movie theater. There was no drive-in, but just an open — open theater, and the people wanted to know, even there were the — at the time, these were the true things. The blitz — the German blitz was so effective that they were taking thousands and thousands of Russian prisoners.

segments.question: Did they ever show Germans taking Jews up? I mean, in — in those reels, newsreels?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did they ever show anything about what their behavior was to the Jews of the east? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala m January 27, 2015
segments.answer: To the Jews of the east, no, I— I don’t remember anything like this, but I remember the operation when we used the eggshells.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Eggshells, we blow up the egg, you know, whites and yellow and —

segments.question: Red?
segments.answer: — and fill it up with — with paint, dark paint.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And we were sitting 1n the first row. And when we saw Hitler delivering some kind of a speech, we used to toss these things against, and you could see the streaks of the things. And then the Germans, after a while, they discontinued this kind of propaganda. They discontinue.

segments.question: Well, of — of — of everything that you were telling me about, this sounds the riskiest, cause if somebody fa —
segments.answer: That was risky, yes. Our operations even there, were done by the young — youngsters —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — they were very risky.

segments.question: Yeah. And yet — and yet, as you describe, it sounds like quite important, not just work. Not just funny work, or something. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala m January 27, 2015
segments.answer: This was important, you know. Even small and let’s say people were looking at us as — as — as misbehaving youngsters doing, and risking sometimes, the lives of the grownups. But this was necessary to keep the morale of the people, and — and the morale of the — Warsaw, occupied Warsaw was very strong, very strong.

segments.question: I want to turn now to the ghetto. Did you see the walls of the ghetto being built?
segments.answer: Yes. This was along the Leszno Street. Leszno Street, which was parallel to Wolska Chiodna thoroughfare that I was saying —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — toward the Kierbedzia bridge. Leszno — there were the county courts, and the brick wall was separating into two halves, the Aryan side and the Jewish side. And that wall, at that particular part, what they did there was ex-execution of Polish hostages, at Narutowicz square, in Ochota district of Warsaw. And there was a rumor that the people that were shot over there, they were brought in and hung on the balcony metal parts, you know, these vertical —

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: — members. They were hung by the necks to — in order to show and let’s say show their punishment toward the Poles, what they can expect if they don’t stay at the bay and — and — and — and — and listen to the — to the authorities of German — the German administration, as a sign of their rule, they wanted to break their Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 113 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 morale. So the pilgrimage of war where [indecipherable] were marching along the Leszno Street, looking at that thing to — to see what was —

segments.question: Did you see that too?
segments.answer: Yes, yes. I personally saw it. There was about 27. And I was wondering if buddy of mine, Kazik(ph), that he was one of them, but I couldn’t recognize. You know, people, when they get shot, you know, they freeze in their position. And you could see that these people were not hung there alive.

segments.question: Oh, I see. So they had already been killed in some form, and were —
segments.answer: Yes, and —

segments.question: — hung there. Okay. And the purpose of it was not — had nothing to do with the ghetto, but it happened to be physically close to the ghetto?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Let’s say on the wall, th — at that time, you know, in order to see some kind of a violent reaction by the Poles, they — the Germans had the two machine guns, I remember, on top of the wall, directed to the Poles marching alongside the wall.

segments.question: Was this a — was this a — was this a mandatory kind of march, you were — you had to go see it?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, the people were forced almost, to see it, yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 114 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay. And then it was — this also at the time when the ghetto wall was being built, or was already built?
segments.answer: No, there — it was already built. That’s — I’m speaking of year, I think was 40 — "43.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: It was about time when the built the bridge. If you saw that pianist movie, there was a bridge from the small ghetto to a large ghetto.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And that bridge was alongside the Zelazna Street, right at that triangular s — triangular park —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — in front of that church of Boramayus(ph) in Warsaw. And nowadays that Father Popieluszko’s, let’s say, park —

segments.question: Mm-hm. Yeah, that’s after the priest who was murdered during solidarity times.
segments.answer: Yes, Popietuszko.

segments.question: Mm-hm, okay.
segments.answer: And this was at the point where the two streets divided, you know, there was one, Chiodna, going toward the Hala Mirowska —

segments.question: Right. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala _ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: — which was like a big marketplace. And the other one was Elektoraina Street, which was going to — to bank — Bank Square. Plac Bankowe, Bank Square, in Warsaw.

segments.question: So does this mean that until then the two ghettos had not been connected?
segments.answer: They never were connected.

segments.question: Even with that bridge?
segments.answer: Let’s say they never — let’s say, they were, on that portion that was from Wronia to Zelazna, they were connected, small and —

segments.question: And large.
segments.answer: — and large. And then, in order to keep the traffic between small and large was that bridge.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Was that bridge, so there were —

segments.question: And so did you —
segments.answer: — connections, yes.

segments.question: Okay. Did you see the building of that bridge?
segments.answer: Yes. I saw it when they were erecting, that was a wooden bridge.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 116 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: That was a wooden bridge. The — I — I have the pictures in that album that I show

segments.question: I— as I say, what’s important for me is not what is published later, but what are your specific recollections. So —
segments.answer: I saw it, yes, because —

segments.question: You saw it.
segments.answer: — I was going to that school for almost a year.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: So almost on a daily basis.

segments.question: And this is where your teach — the school where your teachers were observing you, and then later recommended that you be part of the AK?
segments.answer: AK.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: They recruited me there, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There was, as I said, Casimira(ph) Bye(ph), and Janina Grotska(ph) — grotes -- Grotska(ph), yeah.

segments.question: And Mrs. Bernisz(ph). Or Miss Bernisz(ph). 117 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And Bernisz(ph) was the third one, yes. That was already when I was going to the sixth grade, but this was a cover-up, because actually I was going to that first year of high school.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But pretending that the schools, the underground schools not — not existed, so —

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: — this was used for a cover-up. Trade schools, and all schools that actually Germans considered that they can stay open, like a little business school. But the higher education was out of question. The poli — Warsaw Polytechnics, which was very large institution, and well-known; the University of Warsaw was also closed, but the faculty, even some of them were murdered in [indecipherable] operation. But some teachers that survived, they used to participate in that underground schooling.

segments.question: I see. Now, in your — in your AK unit, you were known only by your pseudonym, not by your real name.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And did you get to be friends with others, or you know, how large was your cell, how — Interview with Thaddeus Gubala “ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: The cell was about [indecipherable] number one was [indecipherable] one was about six, seven guys. I knew them all, because we had the meetings.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We were getting instructions, we were getting training.

segments.question: Did you ever know their real names?
segments.answer: Yes, some of them I knew, yes, yes.

segments.question: And they knew your real name?
segments.answer: Yes, but we was — we were penalized if we used any family names.

segments.question: Okay. Okay.
segments.answer: You know, this — this underground, that was actually there was the — one of the largest underground the world, in — in occupied Europe, by the Germans. We had — AK had the connections, and there were planes coming from England to Poland to pick up some representatives to the Polish government in London, and some important people. So there were a lot of, how should I say, connections and the practical sharing of certain, let’s say, things that were very valuable.

segments.question: Did you know that at the time?
segments.answer: About the planes that were coming to Poland? No —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — no, no. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala m January 27, 2015

segments.question: We need to distinguish that, because —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — then it gets murky.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Where it is, the — the adult Thaddeus Gubala is talking about something, and where it is the experience of the child.
segments.answer: Mm-hm, mm-hm. I didn’t know the operation, the secret operation, but after the war I was engrossed in all kind of reading books, whatever I could find, because we were, let’s say, eager to learn what was happening behind our backs, you know, at that time.

segments.question: Sure, sure.
segments.answer: So, the underground was very effective, and very helpful to the allies.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I don’t know if I can mention right now —

segments.question: If it’s your — excuse me, I’m going to interrupt; is it your experience?
segments.answer: That was my experience that I knew the operations, and the help that we were getting from England.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah. 120 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Then tell me about it.
segments.answer: Because we were getting the — I mean, the higher groups, there was even money sent to Poland.

segments.question: And did you ever see any of it?
segments.answer: No, I would — I wasn’t paid in —

segments.question: In money.
segments.answer: — dollars, no.

segments.question: Were you paid in anything?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We were — we were the youngsters, and very helpful in the operation, but sort of secondary help.

segments.question: Well, you’re young —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — you’re children. And I’m sure they didn’t want to put you in too much danger.
segments.answer: That’s right. Even during the uprising, we were not subject to the strict military rules.

segments.question: Yeah. Tell me wi — I want to come now to the — both uprisings. Did you see any part of the ghetto uprising? Interview with Thaddeus Gubala ms January 27, 2015
segments.answer: As I was walking to school, this was, I think toward the end of May — no, toward the end of April, because May, th-the uprising stopped. It was liquidated by, I would say, May 19, I believe.

segments.question: I think it — I don’t know the exact date, but I think it was mid-April that it started.
segments.answer: Yes, mid-April.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: During that time, the ghetto was on fire. General Stroop, he brought to ghetto — he brought the Ukrainians that were serving with the Germans. I notice Latvians, because they had different, dark uniforms that were part of the guard, around. And there were Germans in the supervisory sort of positions as military. This — what I notice, that a lot of people on the Aryan side were looking from the gates of their apartments, you know, looking toward the ghetto to see how sometimes people were throwing people out of the windows. Instead of being burned, you know, they committed suicide. I saw flames coming out because the Germans actually set fire as they were conquering —

segments.question: Clearing up, yeah, right.
segments.answer: — clearing up the — the segments. I saw this, yes. Because that point of bridge, you know, that I said, two divided streets, Elektoraina and Chiodna, this was a 122 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 main gate. Main gate. Across kitty corner from that building there, there was Vacha(ph), there was a very strong German point that the guardsmen were the Feldpolizei; that was the military police, you know —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — they were armed, and there was a bunker, bunk — concrete bunker to protect their segment of the building. The building is — even now that’s standing, it survived the uprising.

segments.question: Wow. Okay.
segments.answer: Yeah. And that bunker actually there is the original bunker that 1s shown in that uprising museum in — in Warsaw.

segments.question: So you would see the flames of these — of the buildings.
segments.answer: Flames, and the people jumping out of the windows, yes.

segments.question: You would see that too?
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Because at —

segments.question: Was there a smell?
segments.answer: — when — when the Germans — when the Germans were setting up fire —

segments.question: Yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 123 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: — at the ground level, you know, and the flames started shooting up, some of them I saw escaping from one building, jumping over to another one just to get away from the buildings that are set on fire.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Very cruel behavior was of the Jewish police.

segments.question: Wa — in what way?
segments.answer: In what way? They were responsible for gathering the Jews for that shipment to Treblinka.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And they were cruel, because they were responsible to deliver that many Jews as the Germans ordered them.

segments.question: Well, what choice did they have?
segments.answer: They were very cruel. And then, the — the —

segments.question: But again, I —
segments.answer: — producer — producer of that film —

segments.question: Mm-hm, which one?
segments.answer: Kanista(ph).

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: When they had the premier of the film in — in — in Tel Aviv — 124 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — the people were whistling and — and — and — and really criticizing that this is not true that the Jews were so cruel toward the Jews.

segments.question: I have to — I —1-it can all be true. I don’t know that. But in — 1n our discussion, if you — if it’s something that you say, I need to substantiate it with, did you see it?
segments.answer: Do — yes, did I see it.

segments.question: And if you saw it — and how — in — in what way did you see it. So, did you see this cruelty?
segments.answer: Yes, I did, yes —

segments.question: In what way”?
segments.answer: —I di—in what way? Where the people were actually were set on fire in the windows, jumping out.

segments.question: All right, by the Jewish police?
segments.answer: Combined forces. There were Jews and there were Germans, and there were Ukrainians guards at the main gate. So I saw this, yes, I saw this.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: I saw, let’s say before the Jewish uprising, I saw the groups of Jews that were recruited to work on the Aryan side for the German factories, whatever they had.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 125 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Marched by the blue policemen, or the German policemen, toward their destination where they were working. There was, let’s say, sometimes 50 - 60 Jews marching through the Aryan side to their place where they worked.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And the behavior of — toward the Jews was awful. I mean, for the Poles that helped the Jew, you know —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — that was the only country in Europe that for helping the Jew, there was a death penalty. The only country in Europe that if they saw you helping Jew, you could be shot on the spot. And if they didn’t do this, then they arrested your family, or even some of the buildings where this occurred, you know —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — they were all liquidated.

segments.question: So you would see — you would see guards be cruel to Jews who were being taken to work outside of the ghetto on the Aryan side?
segments.answer: Yes. There was kicking, pushing, shouting, and things like this, yes.

segments.question: Okay. Did — oh, I had a question, and it just escaped my mind. And you saw people jumping from roof to roof while the ghetto uprising was going on?
segments.answer: As the flames were spreading out, they were running away, yes. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 126 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Did — was there a smell coming from the ghetto?
segments.answer: Oh yes, day and night, because the Germans were bombing ghetto during the night. There were — they brought heavy guns, and they were using the armor cars when the uprising started, because the group of fighting Jews, there was about 350 of them, you know, that some of them were equipped with the weapons delivered by the AK, and they were heroic in their attempt. They knew that this 1s the only solution, is to die fighting.

segments.question: Did — were there any Jewish boys in your cell?
segments.answer: In my cell no, no.

segments.question: Were there any in the — in that category in the AK, you know — you know, 1n this youngest age category, that you knew of?
segments.answer: Repeat that question.

segments.question: Okay. You explained to me there were three categories; the gray —
segments.answer: Gray ranks —

segments.question: The Gray Ranks.
segments.answer: Zawiszacy.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Szkoly Boyowa.

segments.question: Yeah, and the oldest. 127 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And then Grupy Szturmowa.

segments.question: Right. In that youngest category, did you know of any Jewish boys who were in there, who might have escaped from the ghetto?
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: There were no Jews, but I heard that there were some —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — 1n the upper ranks.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: In the upper ranks. And especially during the uprising — maybe I’m time-wise jumping too far ahead.

segments.question: Which, which, the Warsaw uprising?
segments.answer: The Warsaw uprising. There were — in the ghetto there were Jews that were brought from Hungary, but they were protected by their skills, you know, tailors, shoemakers that were contributing to the war machine.

segments.question: The German war machine.
segments.answer: The German war machine.

segments.question: Right. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 128 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And Zoska battalion, which was one of the leading scouts, but — Boy Scouts, but they were a— 18 and up. So they freed about 350, and they called the gang Shufka(ph). Gesia Street was the street in the ghetto, and they had these barracks where they were working —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — for the German war machine. So some of these guys joined the Polish units during the Warsaw uprising.

segments.question: When they were liberated, however, when were they liberated, by the — by the si
segments.answer: By the AK people.

segments.question: Yeah, when?
segments.answer: This was 1944, I would say the middle of — middle of August.

segments.question: But my question is, by that point, the ghetto is obliterated. There 1s no more ghetto. The uprising had been put down —
segments.answer: Yes, the ghetto — the ghetto was put out.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I’m speaking of some remains of the skilled Jews that were used for the war machine, that were separated from the rest of the Jews in — in Shufka(ph), and these were the Hungarian Jews that were kept. 129 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
