segments.question: Okay. Hungarian Jews weren’t deported from Hungary until March ’44. So, in other words, they couldn’t have been part of the Warsaw ghetto. They couldn’t have been part of the Warsaw ghetto that was obliterated, and yet they’re kept alive. They must have been brought in later.
segments.answer: I think so. It could be like this, because there was even a negotiation between the allies, the — the Germans demanded trucks for trading freedom for these Jews. There was something secret that I — I never, let’s say, analyzed this so deep, but they were trying to save the Jews by giving some —

segments.question: Getting some materials for them.
segments.answer: — material for them.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: But these Jews were brought from Hungary, yes.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Hungarian Jews.

segments.question: So, it would have been in °44.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Rather than — rather than any time earlier.
segments.answer: Yes, yes. And these —

segments.question: And that would have been when the ghetto was already a — a— gone. Interview with Thaddeus Gubala _ January 27, 2015
segments.answer: No, the ghetto, the ghetto, the small and large one was already finished.

segments.question: Yeah, okay. Okay, so let’s talk about your activities in 1943, and 1944, until the Warsaw uprising.
segments.answer: Well, these activities I mentioned to you, the little sabotage that we had —

segments.question: It continued.
segments.answer: — on the bridges, and then the posters, and then the inscriptions of PW —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — in different places, to show that we still existing. And marking the theaters and the — sabotaging the German propaganda slogans. So, this was the activity of 1942 - °43, until the uprising, yes.

segments.question: So let’s turn to the uprising. How do you — what ha — what do you get involved in, what changes in your life to prepare to —
segments.answer: What happened, the uprising started on the first of August.

segments.question: Right, and where were you?
segments.answer: I was near — near that Janusz Korezak building, and —

segments.question: Where the orphanage was.
segments.answer: Orph — the cro — across the street, yes, and the last meeting we had with the patrol one, we said that we are going together at Kartselak(ph), which was a marketplace right at the Wolska Street, that main thoroughfare, and Towarowa, Interview with Thaddeus Gubala _ January 27, 2015 and Przyokopowa, this was a large square, like a Maxwell Street in Chicago, you know, there were little stands that the people were selling. Anything that your heart desire, the black market at that time.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So, the meeting didn’t come through because of the beginning of uprising was scheduled for five o’clock [indecipherable] stands for walka(ph). And there was supposed to be at five, but it started at the different time. So what happened was that I simply joined the newly formed company, 315, across the street in that building of Janusz Korczak.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And what the — happened, they assigned me to be the observer. So I was posted on that highest point of that building that was safe from that siege during the 1939. And I was watching the Germans coming Karolkowa Street, toward the Wolska. This was street — side street, but anyway important, because they tried to clear both sides of Wolska, so the German traffic would go free, without any side — side attacks. But what we did over first and second of the uprising day, we build a barricade and a deep ditch on Karolkowa Street. So the Germans, when they came over, to the point I saw them, I was reporting down that there is a German armor car waiting, but they hesitating to cross because of the obstacle. Then — this was couple 132 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 days like this, and then, before — actually, before uprising started, I was put to work by cleaning some old rifles that were recovered from the hiding places, for an attack by the grownups, of that School 100. Because School 100 that I attended during — before the war —

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: — this whole building was converted to a rest house for the Germans. All the nicer buildings —

segments.question: The beautiful building where you didn’t walk with shoes. Where you walked on your si —
segments.answer: Yes, yes, this was converted to a shelter for the Germans that were coming to Warsaw to rest, after the battle fatigue —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: — whatever they had in the east, or — they were re-convalescence after they were wounded, whatever. Most of the better buildings were taken by the Germans, by the Germans. So anyway, this attack failed, because the Germans were armed to the —

segments.question: Teeth.
segments.answer: — kin. And this thing was a failure.

segments.question: Okay. 133 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: So the next operation, what happened was, on the V separation of two streets, Towarowa and Przyokopowa, there was a German repair shop, for German vehicles. So, we were told that we have to get gasoline for the Molotov cocktails. And I remember from 1939 I had these flare — flare gun.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: That was my weapon. There was one guy that — with the saw off Mauser, you know, carbine? Anyway, when we — there was about five of us, two mechanics, and there were two, three of younger ones, you know, and we entered that place, the Germans got scared off. They got on a— motorbikes, and they left. So we started getting the cars into some kind of a position that maybe we can start —

segments.question: Drive them out.
segments.answer: — drive them out. So one of the mechanics, you know, he was able to — the car had the four tires on. The others didn’t have the tires on because they were over the — what they call, the tunnels, that they were —

segments.question: That’s right, where they were repairing.
segments.answer: Repairing, yeah.

segments.question: Repairing things.
segments.answer: So the one with the four tires was okay, so he started this car. But in the meantime, what I was doing 1s I was collecting into jerry cans — 134 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: You know the jerry cans are.

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: Those 20 liter —

segments.question: Yes, yes, yes, yes, okay, right.
segments.answer: — metal containers. I was sucking — siphoning the gasoline from the ones that —

segments.question: Were on ther — right.
segments.answer: — have the tires on, that was getting ready for repairs.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So I was able to put about two — two — two of these canisters, jerry cans —

segments.question: How were you siphoning?
segments.answer: With the rubber hose.

segments.question: And you were sucking it in?
segments.answer: Sucking it in. Once it started, you know, then the gasoline was dripping out. Anyway, I was — this was the most precious liquid at the time, because the company 315 was waiting for delivery of weapons, but it never materialized, you know, they didn’t get it. So the most effective weapons were the Molotov cocktails. Some of the units that were on the barricade on Gorezewska Street, parallel to Wolska, right at Miynarska, these were barricades attacked by the Germans, and they were trying 135 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 to really break the opposition at any cost. They were even putting civilians in front of their tanks, and — and — and approaching the Polish points of resistance —

segments.question: With the civilians in front?
segments.answer: Yeah, so we would stop shooting, you know, at our own people. And anyway, I delivered — I could carry the whole jerry can, but I take half of it, couple times. I walked from Krochmaina, from that Janusz Korezak place, and | carried this over to Gorcezewska Street, which was a distance of at least five, six, seven blocks, as a small kid, with a friend of mine.

segments.question: That’s not — that’s not bad —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: — that’s quite a bit.
segments.answer: And you know, they welcomed me at the barricade when I brought that gasoline, because whenever Germans approached — and the houses on the left, and on the right, you know, had these bottles, you know, these things were very dangerous for the Germans [indecipherable] we set the fire to a tank, you know, the — the — the crew was jumping out.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So this was one of the major operations. Then this other one — oh, this was something that I’ll never forget. We were told, for the areas that were already freed 136 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 from the Germans, to hang our national flags in front of the houses. And this was a — boo-boo, because the Germans marked the areas they saw the flags; there were observation planes flying over, and three Stukas came over, and bombed again, the area where we lived in.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: They flatten it out. I remember as a ki — that I was — I —I was holding a—a-—a radiator, you know, on the first floor, and somehow I was found semi-conscious in the — in the basement.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: From that flattening out?
segments.answer: From that flattening out. And then, after this, we all took a shelter in the Korezak’s building — Korezak’s building. And then — that was August third or fourth, the Germans brought R.O.N.A., you heard of R.O.N.A.? R-o-n-a. That was Russkaya Osvoboditelnaya Narodnaya Armiya.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: The Russian freedom — freedom army. This was General Vlasov, you heard of General Vlasov?

segments.question: Yes. 137 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: This was a traitor. This wa — he was a Russian, and he recruited the Ukrainians, and Russians, whoever was available, and some — some Mongols from the Azure, to put them to work on Poles, the rebellious Poles, and finish us off.

segments.question: So in other words, this was a group of Russians who were —
segments.answer: Volunteer —

segments.question: — Russians and other Soviets who were against the Soviet Union. That is the —
segments.answer: Yes, Vlasov, yeah.

segments.question: Yeah, Vlasov armies.
segments.answer: Vlasov army.

segments.question: And they not only were against the Soviet Union, but they joined forces with the Germans, with the Nazis.
segments.answer: Yes. They had the Cossacks —

segments.question: Hat?
segments.answer: — hats, with the Hakenkreuz, and the German Wehrmacht uniforms, and some of them had the SS marks. So they were special troops.

segments.question: So what was this — what was distinguished about them, aside from their look?
segments.answer: Aside from them look, they had that R.O.N.A. badges on their left arms.

segments.question: Okay. And what did they do? 138 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: And they were used to especially quench the partisan war — partisan war in the countries occupied by the German armies. These were under the command of General Bach, von dem Bach.

segments.question: Von dem Bach, okay.
segments.answer: Von dem Bach. He was in charge, a specialist for the partisan warfare. He was in Warsaw operation on, I think, the fourth or fifth of August. And he was the guy that stopped the mass mor — murders of that district Wola. Because during that time when the R.O.N.A. came into picture, and they started shooting civilians, 50,000 of ar — Soviets lost their lives because they were cleaning up, mercilessly, all the side streets, and every courtyard was a cemetery.

segments.question: So they were indiscriminate in who they were shooting?
segments.answer: Yes, yes. To the point when that was the fifth or sixth of August, I was in the courtyard — that’s where we lived — and I was in the basement, and some civilians went into basements and they were hiding there. The windows were covered with the sandbags, and some metal plates to protect from any kind of outside attack. When the R.O.N.A. soldiers came over, they had this German potato mashers, you know, these grenades with that little handle on? They used to combine these grenades together and make the bundle of them, and they used to open that little windows and they were tossing into the basement of people. And this was almost 139 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 unbelievable scream of people dying in the basements. And they took us, the live ones, they took us outside the building. You know, my father was already with — old men separated, and I was pulled by the women on the left side. They put some kind of a babushka on my head.

segments.question: A kerchief on your head?
segments.answer: Yes, and they took us into captivity, we were running along this street of Krochmaina, then Karolkowa, to Wolska Street, then we kept running westbound on Wolska Street. And that time I saw last time my father standing already with the hands up in front of Biernatzki — Biernatzki Palace. That was a big structure right in the back of that Clement’s church. There was the last time I saw my father.

segments.question: Oh really?
segments.answer: Yes. And we were driven by force, running all the way to Warsaw west station. The electrical trains were still operating, Warsaw west.

segments.question: Do you know what — excuse me, I’m going to inter — do you know what happened to your father?
segments.answer: Well, there were two stories that I heard. That the executions of men during the vols — vol — vol — Wola massacre, the execution of the men were two places: one, the Saint Albert church on Wolska Street, and then Franaszek factory. This was chemical factory when they were executing men by hundreds and hundreds of them. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 140 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 And when they ki — were killed, I heard that they were piled up, you know, the live ones were piling the dead ones, and pouring gasoline over, and burning.

segments.question: And you think that he’s in either one of these places?
segments.answer: Yes, yes. And I think there is a cemetery, Wolski Cmentarz. Wolski cemetery, that they say that they buried ashes of about 50 - 60,000 people from Warsaw, all over. They were exhuming the dead and burning them. And by weighing, you know, how much ash you get from one person, there were some 12 or 14 big trucks carrying the ashes into a common grave at Wolski Cmentarz. And I visited this place last time I was there in August. And there was a big ceremony, there was American ambassador, there were Polish president Komorowski, and our new allies there was the German Bundeswehr, two officers, I took some pictures of them; politely watching what was happening there. It was a big ceremony, and the people came and by — by hundreds, thousands almost, to participate. They were four spiritual leaders. There was a rabbi, there was Orthodox church, there was evangelical pastor, and a Catholic, you know. And they were all praying for those that were — this is the largest cemetery in the world actually, of 50 - 60,000 ashes of people buried. And they have the whole yard [indecipherable] to build with these stones, you know, they look like a skull. And one older woman, she said, do you know the symbol of these stones? But this is large area I’m speaking of. And I said 141 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 no, I don’t know. These are supposed to, let’s say symbolize the heads of the people that were buried there. Wolski Cmentarz.

segments.question: Wolski Cmentarz. What happened to your mother and sister?
segments.answer: Mother and sisters, they were all put into concentration camp Pruszkow. Pruszkow was concentration camp 121. Pruszkéw was the station, let’s say, in the western part of the city. That’s where they converted railroad repair shop into a camp for the civilians brought to it.

segments.question: Got it.
segments.answer: So when we were in Pruszkéw, the 600,000 [indecipherable] went through two camps: Ozarow and Pruszkow.

segments.question: And I had interrupted you to find out about your father. So you were telling me where you were being herded to, more or less, you were being forced to run to.
segments.answer: Yes, this was —

segments.question: So-
segments.answer: —to Warsaw west. Warszawa zachodnia, Warsaw west. That’s where we boarded the trains that took us over to Pruszkéw, that was I don’t know, 20 kilometers away. Pruszkow was a camp where they were loading us into cattle cars after two, three days of — of tremendous, tumultuous situation. People were looking for each other, lost you know, wounded, sick. There was a Red Cross, and there was 142 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 that help e — help. This whole thing was a chaos, you know, there was the — people were shocked. They were s-semi-alive. They were put by 70 to a freight car. When they loaded the freight car, there was about 40 — 40 — 40 cattle cars. And that train moved toward Reich, toward Germany. And we were transported — the first stop after seven days, no water, no nothing, you know, the car was locked. And there were —

segments.question: No food, no water.
segments.answer: Yeah, and there was barbed wire in the windows. We had one — one older guy with the — with the knife, scissors. So he was cutting the openings in the floor of that car, so this was our —

segments.question: Toilet?
segments.answer: — toilet. Toilet, yes. There was 70 people almost, in the car. You know, first stop was Oranienburg. You heard of Oranienburg? It was a concentration camp that the Germans built — built for the Germans, and all those that did not comply with the German philosophy —

segments.question: Politics, right, right.
segments.answer: — yes. So the — first were Germans. And then, what happened there, there was night, and I remember Berlin on fire, you know, there was — under bombing, and I think that the British at night were bombing it, because they were throwing these Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 143 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 phosphor bombs, and they looked like a Christmas tree. So anyway, I peeped through that hole —

segments.question: And this was probably late August, or something? When was this, mid-August, late August?
segments.answer: That was the beginning of August. There was the seven — no, eight te — middle, middle, yeah.

segments.question: Middle of August.
segments.answer: Middle of August. And when we stopped there, what happened 1s that they disconnected three or four cars. And the train was moving at night, not during the daytime, because daytime, any moving train was attacked by the —

segments.question: Allies.
segments.answer: — by the allied, you know, so at night we moved, and the next stop was Weimar.

segments.question: Oh yeah.
segments.answer: Weimar, near to Buchenwald.

segments.question: Exactly, exactly.
segments.answer: Yeah. That was a place that Schiller and Goethe was creating.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Yes, Weimar.

segments.question: A buti — 1-1t’s the biggest irony. It’s a beautiful little town. 144 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: And right next to it is Buchenwald.
segments.answer: Buchenwald, yes.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And so they disconnected three or four cars. They were distributing the mar — th- the manpower according to whatever they —

segments.question: Needed.
segments.answer: — scheduled, yes.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So after that, you know, the train started moving at night again, and the next stop, I— I— we knew already that something’s gonna happen there. We don’t — I use the word [indecipherable] you know, as I mentioned to you on the phone, that you didn’t know the expression —

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: — that we either will be freed going through a stack, though a chimney.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Or we wil — gonna be put to work for the Reich.

segments.question: Yeah. 145 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015
segments.answer: So when they moved the train from Weimar, Buchenwald, the next stop was, after a few days — at night, we travel at night, and we stopped at Bergen-Belsen. The —

segments.question: Oh, you were making all the tourist stops.
segments.answer: The sightseeing tour, nice.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Bergen-Belsen was a place well-known already. That’s where they killed many, many Jewish people and international people that were kept in the — 1n this death machine. So again, there was a segregation commission. We were out in the field, you know, so latrines were dug up, so we could satisfy our physical necessities there. And after medical commission, you know, they, luckily, put us into a group of people that can be still used for work.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And then Bergen-Belsen, they took us to camp. This was near Hannover, Lehrte, Lehrte, l-e-h-r-t-e, Lehrte.

segments.question: Lehrte, mm-hm.
segments.answer: And this was a junction, a railroad junction, important ra-railroad junction between Hannover and all the ruhrgebeit(ph) coming through Hannover toward Berlin [indecipherable] Berlin and all the other main cities. So there — the camp 146 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 was located on the — right by the railroad junction. There were at least four or five railroad tracks, the main ones. Inside was the reloading ramps, about seven or eight reloading zebs — that they were distributing the war material, packages on whatever the Germans stole in the western Europe, you know, that were sending over to their families in Germany. So we worked for 12 hours a day.

In this camp, there was international society. They were French, they were Belgians, they —

And this camp had the Frenchmen, Belgians, and there was a — a — Yugoslavs that — not the Tito guys, but Mikhailovich? 147 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015

The transit military, Germans that were in transit, you know, going from place to place during the alert, they used to go in there. And we were at the very top. So some of the prisoners of war that signed the agreement that they would like to work for the — you know, as civilians, they were there. So they put us in the very top. We used to sing songs, and all the things that the Germans were getting so aggravated, you know, because we were happy when the bombing was going on. Praying more and more. That was one scene. Another 150 Interview with Thaddeus Gubala January 27, 2015 scene was that th — there were transports of cattle. They pulled the cattle trains along the ramps, and they sounded the alert. Sometimes alert lasted for three, four, or five days.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: So they pulled the trains away, during the alert, they pulled the trains away so they would protect the material, whatever it was there. But when the bombed the train, they opened up these cattle cars. You know, there were so many cows out in the field, running away.

segments.question: Course. Poor animals.
segments.answer: That we started cutting the meat from these cows, and taking it to the barracks, and we smeared the smell of the meat all over the place, so when the German guards came over with the dogs, the dogs were going crazy, because we were hiding the meat in the attics of the barracks. Then we had the meat for a couple days, cooking and eating and so on. You know, this —

segments.question: And yet the dogs were only smelling the blood.
segments.answer: Yeah. They were going crazy. Another scene I remember; we were in the movie barrack, movie barrack, they were showing us their victorious times. Suddenly, explosion took place, a big explosion. These covers that were closing the windows, you know, were blown out. We saw flames all over the place. We run out of the Interview with Thaddeus Gubala mt January 27, 2015 barracks, and we saw a plane that was shot down, and landed right between the two rows of barracks.

segments.question: Oh wow.

segments.answer: No, this is — this is a de-delicate matter, because the allies were trying to convince us to return back — to — to remove us from their backs, because there was one and a half million refugees, slave laborers in Germany, and the countries of their origin were already under Russian occupation. segments.answer: Th—no, no pressure to send us back, because the pressure we simply defied in a way, that the free Poles, free armed forces were protecting us.

segments.question: Okay.

Should I sign a two year contract and go down yonder, and chase the rabbits for the government for two years, or should I go to U.S.A.?
